title: loretto-school-pupil-hector-macrae-wins-prize-climate-change-artwork
story: Hector MacRae, , from Pencaitland, a pupil at Loretto School in Musselburgh, created lsquoClarence the crabrsquo from cans, pen lids and rope from fishermenrsquos nets.His marine design was awarded a special merit prize for S- pupils in the lsquoClimate Changersquo category of the National Galleries of Scotland competition and is being exhibited at the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art in Edinburgh.Hector was inspired by a sustainability project devised by art teacher Heather Manson for a school activity week, which looked at using art to raise awareness of climate change and everyonersquos responsibility as global citizens.Pupils engaged in discussions and worked out ways to slow down global warming. They looked at the scientic properties of everyday domestic products, their recyclability, biodegradability and effect on the marine environment.Using objects that they would find washed up on beaches, the pupils created works to raise awareness of their harm to marine le.Ann Buchanan, Lorettorsquos head of art and history of art, said: ldquoWe are thrilled that Hector was awarded one of the seven special merit prizes for S- pupils in Scotland.

title: musselburgh-conservation-society-appoints-finlay-lockie-new-patron
story: Shipping company founder Finlay Lockie succeeds Lord Cameron of Lochbroom, who retired recently after  years in the post.Mr Lockie said: ldquoThe invitation from Musselburgh Conservation Society to be its patron came as a surprise and a huge honour ndash the more so because of the very distinguished men who had hitherto occupied that position.ldquoI hope I will be able to contribute something to the society and its objectives.ldquoI am particularly keen that the society should respond sufficiently early to policy, in particular draft Local Development Plans, so as to help ensure that conservation can be embodied in the thinking that lies behind those plans from the outset.ldquoThis, though time-consuming and dficult, is vitalwe are to be successful in resisting inidual planning applications which take insufficient account of conservation principles, or indeed councillors for whom development at any cost might override good conservation practice in our area.ldquoIt has been my experience that where we have a sound policy basis upon which to found an argument, it is much easier to persuade those who need to be persuaded, of the importance of conservation in planning.ldquoThis, I believe, is one way in which we as a society can be an effective force for good.ldquoThe responses to inidual applications are, of course, the other part of the societyrsquos work. But let us not forget that we should aim, in doing our work, also to enjoy our shared enthusiasm for our amazing built heritage and the social side too.ldquoI am looking forward to watching the forthcoming lectures on Zoom and hope that mine on the subject of saving Northfield House will be worthy of the others in the lecture series.Northfield House, Prestonpans, was a project taken on by Mr Lockie and his family when the property was bought from the marriage contract trustees of Walter Schomberg Hepburn Scott in .By then, the house and garden were derelict, having been unoccupied for three years and neglected for many more.Mr Lockie started a -year process of preservation, the bulk of the work having been carried out by himself, with occasional assistance from his brother Hamish, a builder. Mr Lockiersquos we Kirsten was a helpful workmate, happy to climb scaffolding and paint windows in cold and dusty conditions.Mr Lockie was born in Edinburgh in  and was educated at the Rudolf Steiner School before starting a career as a lawyer having qualied from Glasgow University.He practised law first in Edinburgh and then in the City of London with a shipping and aviation law firm. In  he set up a shipping company which at its height owned and operated seven handy-sized bulk carriers, some of which called regularly with bauxite at Alcanrsquos aluminium plant in Burntisland.Mr Lockie and his we, along with their children Jamie and Alice, are set to move in the near future to another house in need of restoration.

title: north-berwick-rbs-claim-chicanery-fresh-bid-home
story: The former Royal Bank of Scotlandhall in North Berwick has been at the centre of a bid by new owners to create a home on the site since it was closed two years ago and sold by the financial institute.However, the hall is an extension to a Category B-listed building which would have been the bank managerrsquos home at one point, and listed building consent was needed to change it, as well as planning permission.Both were refused by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department, and appeals failed.Now, owners have appealed to the councilrsquos Local Review Body for a second time after an alternative proposal to demolish the hall and build a home, which woulduse the basement and first floor as a private residence and provide space in the ground floor for lsquopop-uprsquo businesses such as a gallery or yoga studio, was also refused.Among concerns raised by planners was the loss of commercial space in the seaside town centre.The latest applicationsaw  objections from local residents, who argued no attempt had been made to market the building for commercial use and the pop-up plan was an attempt to ldquominimally satisfy planning officers.One objector said: ldquoThis chicanery is ultimately a bad faith gesture designed to circumvent policy.Another complained that a report on its viability as a commercial property compared the building, on Westgate, to office space in Tranent, Musselburgh and Ormiston, adding: ldquoAnyone involved in property would not reasonably expect s rent ot be the same in these towns as in North Berwick, which commands a premium.North Berwick Community Council objected to the plans, stating there was a clear demand for office and business space on the townrsquos High Street.Planning permissionwas refused on the grounds of the loss of commercial space and impact of proposed new build on the character of the area and amenity. The appeal goes before the Local Review Body next month.

title: residents-johnny-moat-place-get-special-bear-hug-lockdown
story: Staff at Johnny Moat Place kept spirits high and gted  residents with a lsquobear in the boxrsquo gt as a positive memento of this yearrsquos lockdown.The kind gesture took place before the Scottish Government announced tighter restrictions on communities last week.Johnny Moat Place is a retirement housing development with one-bedroom flats suitable for those over , run by the charity Bield.Ada Johnston, casual staff member, said: ldquoItrsquos really fortunate that no one at the development has contracted the virus however, like many, it was a tough time for our customers, who have not been able to receive any visitors and have been restricted to their flats. As we started to move out of lockdown, staff got together to think of ways to show our appreciation.ldquoWe found a lsquoCeramic Bear in a Boxrsquo gt and thought it was quite fitting as the message was lsquoSometimes all you need is a big bear hugrsquo ndash which is something many will resonate with after the last few months.ldquoWe put the gts into inidual bags and delivered to each customerrsquos door.ldquoThey were delighted ndash many quite overwhelmed ndash which made our gesture totally worthwhile.Staff were doing their bit throughout lockdown to help those at the housing development by carrying out basic shopping for those with no family or friends close by.They also frequently provided afternoon tea for residents in their inidual flats.Johnny Moat Place offers a meals service however, not everyone uses it, so staff visited each flat every day with tea, coffee and biscuits, providing people with some interaction as well as treats.The development also recently received a socially distanced visit from the local day centre, bringing cakes and flowers. The local branch of the Salvation Army also regularly visited the development to entertain residents.For VE Day, residents received a visit from performers, with some residents watching while sitting outside and others watching or listening from their windows.Johnny Moat Place backs onto the P- campus of Preston Tower Primary School, where a hub was available for children of key workers and vulnerable families.The developmentrsquos scheme manager Katrina Cunningham gave treats to the children, who showed their appreciation by making thank you cards and posters, which now have pride of place in the office window.Ada added: ldquoIn recent weeks, our customers at long last have been able to have limited contact with family and friends which has been amazing. Although our communal areas remain closed, customers have been able to have a visit from the regular hairdresser in their own flat.ldquoAs adevelopment we look forward to the day we can reopen our communal lounge ndash in the meantime, we will continue to do what we can to maintain the spirits and health of our customers.

title: prestonpans-couple-celebrate-diamond-wedding-anniversary
story: Andrew and Jessie Davie, of Prestongrange Terrace, Prestonpans, toasted  years of marriage on September , and had a small service at Our Lady of Loretto and St Michael Catholic Church, Musselburgh, followed by the trip away, just before lockdown restrictions were tightened.The couple, who have six children,  grandchildren and two great grandchildren, met at St Gabrielrsquos Church lsquomixed youthrsquo services and have lived in Prestonpans all their lives.Before retirement, Jessie, , was a shop assistant at CA clothing store, while Andrew, , was in the army, then worked with McVitiersquos Biscuits before setting up his own catering business.Daughter Ruth said the secret to their success was ldquotheir family, their gardening and their friends.She added: ldquoTheyrsquore really into gardening they grow a lot of their own.ldquoThey grow potatoes and seed their own vegetables and they love flowers that keeps them quite active.ldquoMumrsquos still really active ndash she plays badminton, she walks everywhere, she swims once a week. story: A ldquosmall number of people from North Berwick High School have tested positive for coronavirus.The news was shared by NHS Lothian and the schoolrsquos headteacher Lauren Rodger this morning.These latest cases are in addition to the two reported last week, one on Wednesday and one on Saturday, making this the third time in a week North Berwick High School has reported positive cases.A number of people have been contacted as they have been in close contact with the confirmed cases.They will all now need to self isolate and each have been issued with the appropriate guidance and advice.The statement from Mrs Rodger and NHS Lothian said: ldquoWe have been working closely with NHS Lothian Health Protection Team and following all national guidance.ldquoIf you have not been contacted directly to tell you your child is a close contact, then there is no requirement to self isolate and your child will be able toto school on Tuesday  October after half term.ldquoIf you have any concerns in the meantime, oryou need to book a COVID- test because your child has developed symptomsplease visit the NHS Inform website or for non-clinical advice call   .ldquoPlease note that a test should only ever be bookedyou or your child has these specics symptoms.ldquoRemember to stay at homeanyone in the household has symptoms of COVID-.Then, a person at Gullane Primary School was confirmed as having tested positive.Headteacher Seonaid MacGillivray shared the news with the school community, saying: "We are aware of person in the school who has tested positive for Covid-."We understand that this is a worrying time but would like to reassure you that we are working closelywith NHS Lothian Health Protection Team and following all national guidance."The tracking process is still ongoing.The statement continued: "A number of people are currently being contacted because they may have been in close and sustained contact with the case and will need to self isolate. title: wallyford-primary-school-confirms-second-positive-coronavirus-case

title: bomb-disposal-team-carry-controlled-explosion-knox-academy-playing-fields

title: clocks-change-weekend-daylight-saving-time-ends
story: Scots will have to change their clocks on Sunday, and well begin to see lighter mornings and darker evenings.Well be moving backby one hour on Sunday, October  at am.The clock reversal happens every year on the last Sunday of October, pushing the UK back into Greenwich Mean Time .Most devices such as phones, computers, laptops and televisions will change automatically, so no need to worry about those.Analog clocks and clocks on applicants such as microwaves and ovens will have to be changed manually.The change was introduced back in  in an effort to save energy and help the war effort during the First World War.The Summer Time Act  advanced the clocks by one hour from May  until October .GMT ends in the spring when we go back to BST.In , GMT ends on Sunday, March  to mark the lsquoofficialrsquo start of summer.

title: make-annual-leave-christmas

title: dave-berry-column-time-bring-berwick-back-berwickshire
story: Historically, county names derive from their principal town ndash for example, the old name for East Lothian was Haddingtonshire.Although Berwick was once the county town of Berwickshire, the last of many border altercations left it in England.Berwick was founded when Northumbria included our own county.It became Scots after Malcolmrsquos victory at Carham in  and prospered while the Normans were preoccupied with consolidating their grip on England.By , Berwick boasted walls, a mint, a castle, and a hospital. Its constables included several Lauders of the Bass. Their writ ran south of the Tweed to include Ancroft, Kyloe, Norham, Belford, Elwick and Tweedmouth, as well as present-day Berwickshire.At a time when the sea was the highway for commerce in heavy goods, South Berwickbecame the richest city in the land, thriving on trade with the Low Counties and Hanseatic Ports in timber, wool and produce from the Merse.English kings coveted its strategic location. While the English were embroiled where, Berwick blossomed. At other times, Berwick changed hands  times until, in , it fell to Richard III. Elizabeth I secured it with massive fortications, which survive intact.With the Union, most of its hinterland stayed in Scotland. For five centuries, this made scant dference beyond legal issues. However, re-establishment of the Scottish Parliament created disparities ndash in free personal care, prescriptions, tuition fees, etc.Resentment at this in Berwick itself was compounded when Berwick District Council was abolished and the town became a remote appendage to Northumberland.The northward bulge of the border between the Cheviots and the sea remains a defensive throwback. This modern anomaly of Berwick and the disparity between its residents and those in its hinterland could be resolved by a plebiscite among the , residents to decidethe border should be shted south from Lamberton Toll to around Lindisfarne, ing the town and southern villages to Berwickshire.Satisfactory as this might be to locals, Westminster is likely to block such a move. This sht of border would reassert Scottish jurisdiction over the same , square miles of North Sea that Tony Blair allocated to England on the quiet  years ago. That seabed is rich ndash richer than Berwick ever was ndash and too rich to ever let go.

title: merryhatton-garden-centre-five-great-plants-home-office
story: This month wersquore looking at how plants make the environment relaxing and healthy, and suggest some easy-care plants for the home office to create a space that helps improve concentration and effective working.The benefits we get from greenery and plants for both our physical and mental wellbeing have been well-documented but,proof were needed,  has amply demonstrated just how important the natural environment is for our health and happiness.With few exceptions, plants improve the quality of the atmosphere ndash both indoors and outdoors ndash by removing CO and air-borne pollutants and re-oxygenating the atmosphere. The important role of plants in reducing pollution is now so widely recognised that many nations are actively promoting large-scale planting of trees.Whilst most of us would be upset to think that there might be poor air quality in our homes, the reality is that common airborne pollutants such as CO, formaldehyde, volatile organic compounds and phthalates from new materials and furnishings are quite normal, and that is exacerbated where the building, furnishings and decoration are new.Working from home offers an opportunity to optimise the air quality in which we work and live, ensuring best conditions. Although therersquos no substitute for opening the window and circulating the air, we live in Scotland and sometimes thatrsquos simply not possible! Cue houseplants to help improve the air quality, reduce noise pollution and generally create a more relaxed, natural environment.Our top  indoor plants:. Chlorophytum Possibly our best-selling indoor plant, this green and white iegated plant is very simple to care for.With research showing that the spider plant is capable of removing up to  per cent of household air-borne toxins in just two days, itrsquos easy to see why itrsquos a customer favourite.The graceful arching habit of the spider plant makes it suitable as either a hanging plant or in a pot on the desk.One interesting feature of the spider plant is that it produces little lsquoplantletsrsquo on stems which can be easily rooted to create a new plant.. Spathiphyllum The peace lily is also a very easy plant to care for, and very attractive with glossy green leaves and pure white flowers. It is an excellent air purier and is particularly good at removing mould spores and household vapours such as benzene, ammonia and acetone.Depending on the iety, the peace lily can range in height from around cm to over one metre.The peace lily is happy in medium to low light levels, making it ideal for the home office. Attractive purely as a foliage plant, yoursquoll encourage more flowering with better light.The peace lily is unlikely to need watering every day and itrsquos best to take your cue from the plant itself. If the leaves begin to droop, itrsquos usually a sign that it needs some water, but be careful and check that itrsquos not because you have over-watered ndash being too generous with water is one of the most common reasons for these plants to fail!. Ficus benjamina Many plants ndash both indoors and outdoors ndash can be useful in reducing noise pollution. So,your home office is in the corner of a room thatrsquos used by other family members, plants with lots of foliage can be a useful way to create an aesthetic room ider and separate noise.There are many weeping fig ieties available, offering a choice of dferent shades of green or iegated silver green or gold green foliage.Weeping figs thrive in areas where there is good light andlight is only available from one direction, growth will be primarily on the light-facing side. Thatrsquos finethe plant is only seen from one side, for exampleitrsquos against a wall, but for all-round foliage, yoursquoll need to rotate the plant occasionally.As with most houseplants, water when the compost is dry to the touch and take care not to over-water.. Monstera One of the most easily recognised indoor plants with an upright habit and large glossy leaves with cuts and holes , itrsquos native to the South American rainforests and it is understood that the leaves have naturally developed these holes and cuts to help the plantrsquos large leaves avoid damage in tropical storms.In the home, it is often grown on a moss pole to provide an anchor for the aerial rootswhich fix into the pole for stability as the plant grows taller.This plant doesnrsquot need a great deal of attention water when the compost becomes dry, and place it in a bright room but preferably not in direct sunlight, and mist the leavesthe humidity seems low.. Sansevieria All Sansevieria are incredibly tough and, for those who believe that they canrsquot keep plants, this is definitely the plant that should change their thinking!There are many dferent ieties of Sansevieria, with dferent common names including the mother-in-lawrsquos tongue because of its sharpness, or the snake plant because of its mottled foliage.These striking plants have upright, rigid leaves which can be flat or cylindrical, green, iegated or even striped depending on iety. With their simple, bold, architectural structure, they are almost sculptural in appearance and requiring minimal attention, theyrsquore tolerant of even the least green-fingered.Of course, these are only a few of the many dferent indoor plants we have in the garden centre where our staff are always happy to give you help and advice on the best plants for your home office. You can also see a selection of plants and care advice on our website at merryhatton

title: working-home-claim-125-hmrc-cant-work-office
story: Weve put together all you need to know on how it works and how to checkyoure eligible.How much could you claim backyoure required to work from home According to HMRC, employees can claim tax relief based on the rate of tax they pay - and you could recoup up to pound per year.Details on Gov.uk state:ldquoYou may be able to claim tax relief for additional household costsyou have to work at home on a regular basis, either for all or part of the week."This includesyou have to work from home because of coronavirus .However -you cannot claim tax reliefyou choose to work from home.Additional costs include things such as heating, metered water bills, home contents insurance, business calls or a new broadband connection.They do not include costs that would stay the same whether you were working at home or in an office, such as mortgage interest, rent or council tax.When did the HMRC online portal launch The online portal launched onOctober .How much can I get You can either claim tax relief on:Those paying the standard tax rate of  per cent, can claim pound. per week , while those paying the higher rate of  per cent, can claim pound. per week.Additional rate taxpayers who pay  per cent can claim pound. a week.How to checkyoureeligible and claim tax reliefTo checkyoursquore eligible,use the online tool on the Gov.uk website.HMRC havesaid you can claim tax relief from the date you began working from home.If your application is approved, then your online portal will adjust your tax code for the  to  tax year.You will then receive the tax relief directly through your salary and this will continue until March .HMRCrsquos interim director general of customer services, Karl Khan, said:ldquoWe want everyone to get the money that they are entitled to, so wersquove made the online service as easy to use as we can - it takes just a few minutes to make a claim.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-october-20-23-1995-1970-1920
story: ROLLERBLADING youngsters were causing concern among residents in Dunbar, reported the East Lothian Courier on October , .Residents fear that the rollerblade craze sweeping across Dunbar could result in serious injury unless facilities are provided for youngsters to practise in safety.Local police and youth club organisers said that ldquohuge numbers were now involved in the sport ndash skating their way to school, rolling at speed along the High Street and whizzing around town car parks.Rollerblades were likely to be popular Christmas presents and therefore even more children were expected to take to the streets in the New Year.Said PC Richardson of Dunbar police: ldquoKids are going about everywhere on them, theyrsquore certainly getting more and more popular.So far they had not been ldquoa particular nuisance.However, PC Richardson added: ldquoWe do get the odd complaint and elderly residents in particular are concerned about the speed they travel at.PARENTS in Tranent were worried about the safety of their children after glass was found scattered about a school playing field, according to The Haddingtonshire Courier of October , .Tranent parents are becoming concerned at the danger which exists for their children because of broken glass scattered about on the Ross High School playing field.Recently, one of the pupils ndash -year-old Thomas Wilson ndash had his hand badly cut when he fell during a rugby match on the school pitch.Now the parents are demanding that some action should be taken to prevent further incidents.A MAN was fined in court for not sending his son to school for a month, The Haddingtonshire Courier reported on October , .In Haddington Sherf Court on Monday, John Pirrie, miner, Tranent, was charged with having for one month before th October failed to send his son regularly to school.The accused was represented by his we, who explained that her husband was in bad health, and unable to appear in Court.Mr J. W. Williamson, solicitor, for the Education Authority, said that the accused had been summoned to attend a meeting of the Committee but had paid no attention to this or to an attendance order which had been issued against him.Sherf MacLeod said the expenses of the prosecution, amounting to pound, s , would have to be paid, andthe boy were not kept regularly at school further penalties were possible.

title: royal-mail-launch-new-doorstep-parcel-pick-up-service-across-uk
story: Weve put together everything you need to know.How will the new service work Households that have packages they need to send can now do so without leaving home for a p charge per parcel, Royal Mail said.The parcels can weigh up to kg and can be a little over twice the size of most airplane hand luggage .It was hailed by the postal service as ldquoone of the biggest changes to the daily delivery since the launch of the post box in .Customers will be able to get their parcels collected every day apart from Sundays.Pre-paidpackages can be collected for p per item.The company has been testing its system in the west of England, but will now roll it out nationwide, it said on Wednesday .What have Royal Mail said about the changes Royal Mail chief commercial officer Nick Landon said:ldquoRoyal Mail Parcel Collect is a fantastic step forward for all of our customers."It makes it easier to use our services than ever before."Changes toservices in recent yearsReturns have become an increasingly important market for the postal system in recent years, as online shoppers want the chance to change the items they bought.It has spawned a new industry of companies to take charge of the s process.Millionaire businessman Lloyd Dorfman has set up Doddle, a company that partners with local shops to simply s, but also offers click-and-collect services.Royal Mail has been forced to rely increasingly on parcels, as letters drop in importance with the advent of email. Since  the number of letters it delivers has halved, even before the pandemic.This year has been particularly harsh. In the three months to the end of June the company delivered  million fewer letters than the same period the year before, down  per cent.The reduction was sped up by Covid-, but even before the pandemic hit, Royal Mail was expecting a drop of up to eight per cent in letter volumes during the  months to the end of March.Meanwhile, parcel volumes have increased greatly.The company has already tried to maximise its presence in the booming parcel market, launching parcel post boxes last year. The first parcel post service was launched in in .

title: decision-close-north-berwick-tsb-branch-branded-short-sighted
story: In a motion to go before East Lothian Council next week, ward councillor Jeremy Findlay will askfellow members to condemn the decision to shut the branch in January  ndash seven months after TSB closed its Dunbar branch in the county.He acknowledges that the decision is part of anational closure programme which will see  branchesclose across the UK, with the loss of  jobs.And he will ask councillors to back the motion statement that: ldquoEast Lothian Council believes that this is a short-sighted decision that does not take intoaccount that East Lothian is the second-fastest growing area in Scotland.The motion, which is seconded by Councillor Lachlan Bruce, opposition leader, calls on the councilrsquos chief executive to write to the chief executive of TSB to expressdisappointment at the decision.It also calls on her to write to the chief executives of all the majorbanks with branches in East Lothian to request information as to the future of thosebranches and highlight the importance of branches being kept open and available to communities.It adds: ldquoEast Lothian Council knows that banks offer vital services and that, for many of our mostvulnerable citizens, the ability to use those services is harmed when they are unable toaccess a physical building due to branch closure.

title: 4-mouth-watering-recipes-make-pumpkin-halloween
story: However, the activity is now so popular that the UK is expected to waste about , tonnes of perfectly edible pumpkin this Halloween ndash but the leftovers can be put to good use.How to reduce pumpkin wasteInstead of throwing out your pumpkin innards once you have finished carving, there are a number of ways you can use your leftovers to help reduce the amount of waste.Weve put togethersome tasty ideas to tryyoursquore looking for inspiration.Pumpkin seed browniesJohn Quigley of Red Onion in Glasgow providedthisrecipe to Zero Waste Scotland.Ingredients:bull g dark chocolate, minimum % cocoa, chopped into small piecesbull g unsalted butterbull g plain flourbull  eggsbull frac vanilla pod, seeds onlybull g soft brown sugarbull g pumpkin seeds, rinsed and left to dryMethod:Toast the pumpkin seeds on a baking tray for - minutes at #C gas mark , set aside to cool.Place the butter and half of the dark chocolate in a bowl and melt together using a bain-marie or microwave.Mix the egg and vanilla together, then add the sugar. Add to the melted butter and chocolate.St in the flour and fold through gently until just combined.Add the remaining chocolate pieces and mix well.Pour into a lined, cm square baking tray and top with the toasted pumpkin seeds.Reduce the oven down to #C gas mark  and bake the brownies for  minutes. If the middle is still wobbly, place back in the oven until just set.Remove from the oven and allow to cool completely before turning out and cutting into squares.Sausage, Apple and Pumpkin BakeTop chef Neil Forbes has shared thisrecipe for a sausage, apple and pumpkin bake.Ingredients:bull Allow three sausages per person bull  medium-sized onions, roughly choppedbull a splash of cold-pressed rapeseed oilbull salt and pepperbull frac pumpkin , roughly choppedbull a few par-boiled potatoes , cut into large chunksbull a knob of butterbull  clove garlic, slicedbull  very large cooking apple , cored and roughly choppedbull a small handful of fennel fronds, roughly choppedbull a sprig of rosemaryMethod:Heat the oil in a large casserole dish or oven-proof pan, and fry the onions and whole sausages. Season with salt and pepper.Add the pumpkin to the pan. Keep stirring and moving the dish around to get colour on all the ingredients. Then add the potatoes, butter, garlic and apples.Make sure everything is starting to colour nicely before placing in the oven for  to  minutes at C Gas Mark  to cook further and brown.Remove from the oven, add the fennel fronds and stir. Serve at the table in the dish you cooked it in ndash no time for pretty presentation here.Pumpkin soupChef Tom Kitchin has suggested this recipe for roasted pumpkin soup.Ingredients:For the stockbull Trimmings and skin from the pumpkinbull ml chicken stockbull  large onion, peeledbull  bunch parsley stalksbull - sprigs of thymebull  cinnamon stick head of garlicbull  celery sticks, roughly choppedbull  carrots, roughly chopped salt and pepperFor the soupbull pumpkin, peeled and cut into  equal wedgesbull  tbsp vegetable oilbull  large onion, peeled and thinly slicedbull  teaspoons ground cinnamonbull  tsp caraway seedsbull  tbsp butterbull  tbsp clear honeybull ml cream salt and pepperMethod:To make the stock, put all the pumpkin skin and trimmings into a large pot and cover with chicken stock. Keep the pumpkin seeds back for roasting.Add the rest of the stock ingredients and simmer slowly for at least one hour.Leave to rest for  minutes and then strain through a sieve.To make the soupDivide the pumpkin wedges into two batches. One batch is for roasting and the other for sweating on top of the stove.Chop the wedges for sweating into cm cubes and set aside. Heat the oil in a large, heavy-bottomed pot over a medium heat.Add the onion,  teaspoon of cinnamon and a good pinch of salt, then sweat gently until the onion is very soft.Add the cubes of pumpkin and cook gently until soft. Add enough stock to cover and leave to simmer.Meanwhile, heat a large frying pan and add the butter. When it begins to foam, put in the large pumpkin wedges, salt and pepper. Allow the pumpkin to colour on both sidesand then sprinkle on  teaspoon of cinnamon and  teaspoon of caraway seeds.Continue to cook, turning occasionally to ensure that they are an even colour. After about  minutes, add the honey and put the pumpkin into the oven at C F Gas Mark  and roast for six to eight minutes until it is dark golden brown.Add the roasted pumpkin to the pot of simmering pumpkin and mix together well, adding more stocknecessary.Leave to cook until the pumpkin is very soft and tender, then add the cream. Check the seasoning and take off heat.Leave to rest for ten minutes before transferring it to a blender and blitzing until smooth. The key to a great soup is a good stock.Or how about a Harry Potter-inspired recipeFinally, Edinburgh chef Mark Greenaway has created thissweet and savoury recipe after being inspired by Harry Potter and The Philosopherrsquos Stone by JK Rowling.Ingredients:bull g puff pastrybull  chicken leg, roasted, meat pickedbull  new potatoes, diced and boiledbull  carrot, diced and boiledbull g roasted pumpkinbull g caster sugarbull seeds of  vanilla podbull ml double creambull  beaten eggMethod:Combine the chicken, potato and carrots in a bowl.Blend the pumpkin, sugar, vanilla and cream, then pass this mixture through a fine sieve and chill in the fridge.Preheat the oven to C Gas Mark . Roll the pastry and cut out two circles roughly cm in diameter.Place the chicken mixture on one half of each pastry circle, then place the sweet pumpkin mixture on the other half. Fold each circle over to create a pasty shape using egg wash on the edges to seal it.Crimp the top with your fingers and brush with egg wash all over. Bake for  minutes.

title: six-vying-snps-east-lothian-candidate-2021-scottish-parliament-elections

title: pictures-historic-17th-century-northfield-house-prestonpans-seven-bedrooms-wine-cellar-sale
story: Northfield House sits on Preston Road near Prestonpans Train Station and is a fully restored and refurbished listed property.It is described by estate agents Savills as a ldquohistoric family home of ldquoimmense character, with ldquointricate period detail and ldquoexcellent potential for a self-contained granny or staff flat.The property can be accessed through a gate which opens up to a gravel courtyard, with parking space for several cars, and a gateway that leads onto a cobbled terrace on the southern elevation of the house.Northfield House sits on . acres of secluded south-facing garden grounds, which the potential owner will also own alongside an external coach house with a slate roof.The gardenrsquos gorgeous greenery and numerous trees provide some privacy and seclude this historic house from the outside world.Several of the old periodic features of the house have been kept, including three four-poster beds, a theme which runs throughout the property.On entering through the front door, the former kitchen and bakehouse, complete with fireplace, on the right side has been turned into a stone barrel vaulted cloakroom with access to a cellar.The door to the left leads onto a store room, which has access to a toilet and cupboard, a second store room follows on which is used for wine storage.Above this second store room is the turreted main stairwell, which also has external access through a th century door and access to the store room, this leads onto the old kitchen.The old kitchen, part of the  extension with the original flagstone floor, leads onto a garden room, this also has external access and is currently used to store garden machinery and tools.The coach house is attached to the main house on the other side of the old kitchen, but it only has external access.A set of lower stone stairs in front of the main door lead to the first floor and principal accommodation.It is thought that the second store room, north turret entrance, old kitchen and garden room ,which have been left unconverted could potentially be used as a granny or staff flat, with their own access to the garden and courtyard.The propertyrsquos unique layout continues to the first floor.On the east side and at the top of the stone stairs lies the kitchen. The opposite door leads onto the hall which then leads onto the dining room, complete with an intricately detailed ceiling, and utility room, also known as the butlerrsquos pantry.The door to the kitchen is a th century oak door. The cupboard doors and shelves are handmade solid timber.A Belfast sink, granite worktops, marmoleum floor, gas fired four oven aga and clothes pully complete the kitchen.Another th century door leads onto the dining room which alongside the hall make up the original great hall.A th century tempura painted beam and board ceiling, marble fireplace, pine floor, window seats and shutters complete the room.At the top of the turreted stairwell, which was remodelled in the s when the main star was constructed, is a door which leads onto a small hallway.The hallway leads onto two bedrooms, both with the same ceiling as the dining room and working fireplaces, and a bathroom complete with heated towel rail.Up the stone stairs with cast iron Greek revival balusters and polished mahogany handrail to the second floor lies the drawing room, the former long gallery with late th century mantlepiece, three more bedrooms and a bathroom.Polished pine flooring flows throughout the second floor with turrets on each corner of the house, one of which is home to a sink.The third floor is home to the attic and the final rooms in the house. It is accessed by wooden stairs opposite the spiral stairwell on the second floor.Another bedroom, storage cupboard and toilet can be found here as can a studio that links to the final bedroom.The current owners have renovated Northfield House over the past  years, which included rebuilding the chimney stacks, overhauling the roof and lead where required, repairing the harling and repainting and replacing the gutters and downpipes.Alongside all of this work, the plumbing has either been replaced or upgraded with a central eating system installed in  along with a new boiler in .To arrange a viewing call Savills   .

title: letter-week-green-belt-now-rust-belt
story: In a bygone age, this sign warned developers off the exploitation of farmland. It also marked the boundaries of Edinburghrsquos expansion. In modern times, the Green Money Belt invites property speculators to fill their boots from the great schemeication of East Lothian.The latest version of the Goshen Farm scheme, which lies within the estate, is moving closer to approval. The plans for another  houses bear all the worn hallmarks of the countless other local housing schemes: car only, no active travel corridors, poor integration with neighbouring communities, net zero local jobs and a dependency on unsustainable commuting. East Lothian parrots the language of a new green world but, when it comes down to shovels and spades, we donrsquot walk the talk, we drive instead.All around Edinburgh, the green belt has morphed into a lsquorust beltrsquo, where once-distinctive industrious communities now serve the city. Is it working  Not when , children in East Lothian live in poverty. Not when the roads are clogged with traffic. Not when the necessary rail upgrades are decades away. Not when the open space we all once took for granted is shrinking before our eyes.The speculators, who make billions by reducing our quality of le, donrsquot live here. If they even bother to look in on the mess their greed helped create it will be remotely from the safety of their gated community.With all the surrounding over-development, it might be tempting just to let the bulldozers rip through the rest of Drummohr. Or instead East Lothian Council could preserve the agricultural landscape and leave a new marker for the future: a permanent reminder of what was lost where and what remains worth defending.Calum MillerCommunity CouncillorPrestonpans

title: longniddry-port-seton-libraries-back-open-new-restrictions
story: Longniddry Library is open for limited browsing in addition to its click and collect service.It also has revised opening hours to Monday-Wednesday and Friday am-pm and -pm, and Saturday am-pm.The number of people entering the library is limited and people are asked to make an appointment before they visit, rules that apply to all of the libraries in East Lothian that are open .Each appointment will last for a maximum of  minutes. Those who attend without an appointment will only be given accessstaff can safely accommodate other customers at the same timenot, an appointment will be booked for a later date.To make an appointment, book online, email or call the relevant library.Port Seton and Tranent Libraries are offering a click and collect service and resuming PC use.They have also introduced limited opening hours, which are am-pm and -pm Tuesday, Thursday and Friday for Port Seton and am-pm and -pm Thursday and Friday and am-pm on Saturday for Tranent.Those who are not a library member or do not have access to the internet are asked to phone either library, where staff will be able to help.Computer bookings will last for an hour per session, with one booking allowed per person per day and fewer computers available to allow for enhanced cleaning.Those who visit any library in East Lothian are asked to wear a face coveringpossible, with one way-systems and staff wearing PPE.

title: prestonpans-couples-celebrate-incredible-100-years-marriage
story: Brothers Wallace, , and Jimmy Hanratty, , were born and brought up in the town.Jimmy was a previous local community police officer in Prestonpans ndash he started his career in Edinburgh and moved to work in Prestonpans in the mid-s he has also been a police officer in Musselburgh.Wallace was previously a builder but more recently a black taxi driver in Edinburgh.The brothers, before the latest coronavirus restrictions closed pubs, bars and restaurants across East Lothian, enjoyed a weekly drink and catch up in Prestonpansrsquo Royal British Legion branch.The pair also love their music and brought their children up listening to s music.Mary, , and Martha Hanratty, ,were also born and brought up in the town however, they lived in Conisbrough in Yorkshire from  to  due to their father Johnrsquos job as a coal miner.Before retirement, Mary worked as a shop assistant and cleaner in places such as Asda and the Co-op and Martha as a shop assistant in places such as the Post Office in Wallyford and shops in Prestonpans.Both couples met as youngsters in Prestonpans at the swing park on Rigley Terrace on New Yearrsquos Day .Martha and Mary came up for New Year with their family and stayed at their granrsquos house they went out to the park, where the boys were playing football, and started talking.The pair moved back to Prestonpans a few months later and would all hang out in one big group.They married on October , , at a double ceremony at St Gabrielrsquos Church in Prestonpans, which saw Mary marry Wallace and Martha marry Jimmy.Their wedding even featured in newspapers at the time.Mary and Wallace went on to have two children together: Gordon, , and Annette, .They are also grandparents to -year-old Caitlin.Martha and Jimmy had three children together: Graham, , Carole, , and Lynn, .When the couple first met, Martha did not like Jimmy however, that soon changed and  years later the couple still love spending time with each other.They also have five grandchildren: Elyse, Erin, Adam, Leah and Lori, whose ages range between  and six.Their secrets to a long and happy marriage  Wallace says ldquodo what yoursquore told, Mary ldquoyou just have to come and go with each other, but Carole suggested that ldquoitrsquos more about the women investing in ear plugs to put up with the snoring.Both couples are very family-orientated and enjoy spending time with their nearest and dearest when they can.They often went on holidays together when their children were teenagers.Wallace and Mary are also members of the local bowling club, with Wallace, a keen Hearts fan, being the founder of Prestonpans Hearts Supporters Club.Wallace has had a season ticket for Hearts for a number of years and often took his children to games when they were young.Mary is a keen bingo player, as is Martha, who never missed her weekly bingo session every Wednesday, and the pair would enjoy games at the British Legion in Prestonpans.Jimmy is a keen walker and golfer and plays with a group of friends twice a week he is former secretary at Royal Musselburgh Golf Club.However, these are not the only marriages between the families.Maryrsquos brother Tommy married Wallacersquos sister Isobel in  the couple are still together and recently enjoyed their th wedding anniversary.Plans to celebrate the big occasion were initially a party at the Royal British Legion in Prestonpans and then a low-key dinner at the Prestoungrange Gothenburg ndash both had to be cancelled due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Annette said: ldquoItrsquos pretty gutting the party had to be cancelled. Everyone in the family loves a party so itrsquos really disappointing.ldquoAll of the children had planned together what we were going to do.ldquoLast year we managed to get and watch some video from the wedding they were surrounded by family and friends. It looked like a lovely ceremony.Instead, both couples enjoyed an afternoon tea at Sweet Boutique in Prestonpans, followed by Zoom calls from their families that evening.

title: macmerry-jim-horse-storms-first-race-win-southwell
story: Macmerry Jim came home in first place in the .pm race at Southwell on October .The two-year-old bay colt takes its name after a chance meeting in a pub on New Yearrsquos Day.Dundee-based Jimmy Fyffe had been watching his horses in action at Musselburgh Racecourse on January  last year.An enjoyable evening in Macmerry Minersrsquo Welfare saw Jimmy strike up a friendship with Jim and Frances Smith.Earlier this year, Jimmy, who is also involved with Dundee United, revealed that he had named his latest horse Macmerry Jim after the village and his new friend.Macmerry Jim has raced three times already, taking second on his debut at Southwell at the end of August.He then finished fth last month at Ayr.Seventy-nine-year-old father-of-four Jim lives on the villagersquos Brierbush Road and previously told the Courier he was ldquohighly delighted with the honour.

title: humpback-whale-spotted-off-east-lothian-coast
story: The animal was spotted on the evening of Sunday, October , in the Firth of Forth off Dunbar, close to the harbour.News of the sighting was posted on Facebook groups Scottish Humpback ID and Forth Marine Mammals.The animal is as long as a bus, between  and . feet, and can weigh as much as  tons.The whale was then spotted the following morning heading north to the Isle of May, off the coast of North Berwick.Humpback whales have been spotted in the Forth over the past three wintersbut had not been spotted since.The animals can usually be seen in the North Sea throughout the year.It is thought that the high numbers of sprat and herring in the area could be what attracted the whale so close to the East Lothian coastline.The exciting news was also shared by the Scottish Seabird Centre, which encouraged people to ldquokeep their eyes peeled and report any sightings.

title: end-era-torness-power-station-station-manager-leaves
story: Robert Gunn has swapped the East Lothian coastline for Suffolk and a new role at Sizewell B Power Station.Mr Gunn, who has been succeeded by Tam Al-Bishawi at the county power station, said: ldquoIrsquom looking forward to a new challenge in a new part of the country but I will miss the team at Torness, who really are some of the top professionals in the industry.During his  years at Torness, to the south-east of Dunbar, the power station has generated enough low-carbon electricity to power about  million homes and the carbon avoided compared to gas generation is the same as taking . million cars off the road.The father-of-three, who has been married to we Kathleen for  years, has worked in a number of technical and leadership roles at Torness, including engineering, business improvement, maintenance, safety and plant performance.He was plant manager before being appointed as station director at the beginning of .Mr Gunn, originally from Glasgow, lived in East Lothian since he started working at the power station, which employs more than  people and  full-time contractors.He told the Courier: ldquoTorness has been a fantastic place to work for almost  years and has gone from strength to strength as we have worked very hard to continuously improve how we operate.ldquoIt is a beautully engineered plant that has safely and reliably provided a quarter of Scotlandrsquos electricity over that period, and of course in a low-carbon manner.ldquoThe staff are what makes it special and Irsquoll miss them all very much as I move to an exciting new opportunity at Sizewell B in Suffolk.ldquoI will also miss East Lothian, though will ensure Irsquom back regularly to visit.The -year-old wished Mr Al-Bishawi, who has been with EDF Energy, which manages Torness, since , the best of luck.Originally joining as a graduate engineer, the -year-old father-of-two has spent his time with the company in ious roles at Torness and Sizewell B.Last year, he was promoted to plant manager at Torness and has delivered best ever operational and safety results.Mr Al-Bishawi, who is also married, said: ldquoItrsquos a real privilege to take on the role of station director at one of the UKrsquos best performing nuclear power stations.ldquoI want to ensure the site continues to safely generate enough low-carbon electricity for up to . million homes a year and I know I have a great team here who will support me in doing this.Alasdair Swan, treasurer of Dunbar Community Council, wished Mr Gunn well in his new role.He said: ldquoHe has been an absolute pleasure to work with and a great supporter of Dunbar.ldquoIt will be our loss and Sizewellrsquos gain.

title: new-20mph-speed-limits-around-east-lothian-made-permanent
story: In total,  towns and villages have been included in the mph regulations introduced for six months in response to Covid- and as part of a move designed to make it easier for people to social distance and travel safely.Several country roads which would normally be covered by the national speed limit have also had a mph restriction imposed.Councillor Norman Hampshire, cabinet environment spokesperson, said that at the end of the six months some of the restrictions could be adopted permanently.He said: ldquoThe Covid- pandemic has greatly changed the way in which people are moving in and around our local towns and villages. title: north-berwick-woman-meg-maitland-swims-english-channel
story: Meg Maitland, , was part of a team of six ndash called the Kangaroos relay team ndash who swam the  miles from Dover to the north of France.Due to coronavirus, the swim was on and off all summer Meg initially planned to complete it in June but had to cancel it due to restrictions.However, the team eventually left Dover on the evening of August  and arrived in Wissant, about  kilometres south-west of Calais in the north of France, the next day.The team left at .pm and swam through the night, reaching their destination  hours and three minutes later.Each swimmer had to complete a leg one hour long, going in rotation until the challenge was complete.The swim ended up being as dficult as it sounded, with some challenging conditions experienced by all along the way.Meg said: ldquoIt was a hard swim trying to beat the currents and waves however, the sea temperature was  degrees, positively balmy for us North Sea swimmers used to anything from four degrees upwards!ldquoAlong the way we passed tankers, ferries, fishing boats and porpoises.ldquoWith teamwork and with a great boat leader, Laura, we made it!ldquoWhat an amazing experience.Due to coronavirus restrictions, only the last swimmer on the rota could approach the French shore and claim the swim done.Completing the swim was something Meg had wanted to do for a very long time.She said: ldquoSince I was seven years old and crossed from Dover to Calais on a ferry, Irsquove wanted to swim the Channel. Nearly  years later in , I applied for a place on a relay organised by Aspire.Aspire, which Meg was raising money for, is a charity that supports people with spinal cord injuries and allows them to live independent lives. The charity often arranges Channel swims by putting teams together from across the UK.Meg said that swimming played a huge part in rehabilitation thanks to its physical and mental benefits.She had to go through a selection process before being offered a place on the team.She trained for nearly one year, followed by the final qualying swim, which saw her swim in water that was  degrees Celsius for two hours wearing just a swimsuit, hat and a pair of goggles.She joked that ldquowater at that temperature is easy to find in Scotland.She added: ldquoIt was a huge team effort to get there and we all felt aswersquod all swum into the beach.ldquoWithout a doubt I wouldnrsquot have achieved this without the other Kangaroos, our boat leader Laura and the organisation from Aspire.ldquoSeveral people and things over the years have helped me achieve this dream. Swimming in the freezing water at Dunbar open-air pool in the rsquos and rsquos the Salty Selkies and the Bass Rock Swimmers of North Berwick, who got me to ditch my wetsuit the RNLI who rescued me and saved my le a few years ago my friend Linda Malcolm, whorsquos swum with me in all weathers and temperatures and finally Alistair Forbes and his dog Bentley.ldquoAlistair watched me swim for years early in the mornings when out walking Bentley. He looked out for me going in and coming back. Seeing him on the green at the anchor whilst I was out swimming was always a reassuring sight.ldquoHe supported my dream... although thought I was mad!ldquoSadly, both he and Bentley passed away this year before the swim was completed, but along with everyone who helped me get there and my long-suffering partner David, they were all with me whilst I was swimming. Thank you and for all the donations to Aspire.Meg has smashed her pound, target with nearly pound, raised so far.Donate at justgiving fundraising channelswimmegmaitland

title: home-approved-site-dunbars-old-amusement-arcade
story: The arcade, off Dunbarrsquos Lamer Street, closed its doors about  years ago before being demolished.Currently, the site is being used as ldquoan unofficial parking area but Mr and Mrs Alan Bell have been given permission to create a two-storey home.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department approved the scheme, despite three letters of opposition.Concerns included that the site would be betterused by the community, oras a restaurant or bar and that it was currently ldquoa useful space for overspill parking.However, planners noted that whether there were alternative uses that would better service the community or the site was being used as a car park were ldquonot material planning considerations.Drawings included within the planning application show how the new house will look.On the ground floor, there will be three bedrooms, as well as a kitchen, living room and dining area.Upstairs features the master bedroom, as well as a dressing room and bathroom.Planners felt the design would ldquopreserve and enhance the character and appearance of the conservation area and would not be harmful to it.The planning officerrsquos report read: ldquoThe proposed house would be of a contemporary architectural style that would be readily visible in public views from the surrounding roads including Lamer Street, The Vennel and Castle Street.ldquoIn those public views, it would appear visibly dferent to the existing buildings in the area.ldquoHowever, due to its relatively low height and that it would be seen against the backdrop of the much larger flatted buildings to the south and west of the site, the proposed house would sit comfortably on its plot and would not dominate or compete with those much larger buildings.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, was among those backing the proposals when they were revealed.She said: ldquoThat site has been an eyesore for decades and whilst there have been lots of conversations about how it might be brought into public ownership or public use, none of them have got off the ground.The vacant site sits beside a playpark and looks out over Dunbarrsquos East Beach.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the town on East Lothian Council, agreed that the site was currently an eyesore.He said: ldquoI know there were quite a lot of people in the community who would have liked to have some type of retail or leisure facility close to the beach but nobody was interested in doing that.ldquoAt least a househellip it is only the one house, there was a proposal previously for quite a number of houses, which would have been quite an impact on the seafront.ldquoJust having the one house will not overpower the Beach House immediately to the rear.ldquoI think it was acceptable that the planners have recommended approval for this application.ldquoIt is going to help to improve the look of the seafront, which has been in decline for a number of years.ldquoThis part has always looked a mess since the arcade was demolished and it just seems a shame the site has been in this condition for a long time.ldquoIt will be nice to see it tidied up and make the seafront attractive again.

title: rachel-broadley-julia-dale-knox-academys-new-head-pupils
story: Rachel Broadley and Julia Dale, who both live in Haddington, took on the senior roles earlier this year, with the school going through a series of changes due to the coronavirus pandemic.Despite those changes, Sue Cook, headteacher at the Haddington secondary school, has tipped the two S pupils to do well in the role.She said: ldquoWhilst being head pupils may seem challenging in the current Covid- climate, Rachel and Julia are already exploring creative ways to take their ideas forward.ldquoSo far they have led a whole school assembly on our achievement ties and also held a senior phase consultation on prelims.ldquoAlong with the pupil leadership team, they are currently planning an assembly on Black Lives Matter, which they hope to share with other East Lothian schools.ldquoI am really enjoying working with them and the extended pupil leadership team, who are very proactive, and I know they will make their mark in their leadership of ious initiatives this year.The traditional process of finding new head pupils was affected by the global pandemic. Interested pupils produced their own manesto, which was uploaded to the school website.Each pupil also had to make a short campaign video, before an interview with teachers, a current pupil and last yearrsquos head pupils.Finally, it came down to a vote.Both pupils told the Courier they were keen on taking on leadership roles.Julia, , who is studying Advanced Higher art, biology and chemistry, said: ldquoI think always through primary school and infant school I was up for leadership roles.ldquoI was class rep and did anything I could to get involved with the school.ldquoIt is something that I have always wanted to do.Rachel was keen to offer support to pupils with problems and particularly exams.The -year-old, who is studying Advanced Higher English and modern studies, as well as Higher history and geography, said: ldquoI want to support pupils through their course choices and generally more information on what is in the course.Ms Cook wished both Julia and Rachel luck, working alongside Thomas Guy, Hugo Elder and Duncan Riley as depute head pupils.She said: ldquoFrom the outset of the campaign process, both Rachel and Julia displayed a quiet calm and confidence, exhibiting the kind of positive approach essential for the role of head pupil.ldquoRachel, throughout her campaign and interview process, displayed a compassionate determination where she put community firmly at the centre of her thinking.ldquoRachel is keen to support our focus on ensuring positive relationships across the school and to hold a conference, run by Ss, for all S pupils, to support them in their senior phase.ldquoJulia, again, was a standout candidate with an unwavering focus on fostering kindness and promoting equity at Knox Academy.ldquoShe is keen to use our lsquonew normalrsquo virtual environment to make YouTube videos to support pupils in a iety of ways, such as P transition through to preparing for exams.

title: coronavirus-nicola-sturgeons-five-tier-lockdown-system-explained
story: The new set of restrictions has been anticipated since a similar three-tiered system was introduced in England by Prime Minister Boris Johnson.If approved at Holyrood next week, the new measures will come into force in Scotland on Monday, November .The three middle tiers will be broadly similar to the English system - with Scotland also introducing a more extreme tier akin to a "fuller lockdown", as well as a lower level with "slightly more freedoms".The First Minister said the decision on what levels each area will apply to will be discussed in coming days and reviewed weekly.Here, we set out what the five tiers mean and what we know so far:Nicola Sturgeon said Level  is "broadly comparable" to the position reached in Scotland in August "when the virus was very suppressed, but still a threat."She added:"At this level, we would be able to meet indoors with  people from  households. And most businesses would be open, albeit with safety measures in place."At Level  there is slightly more restrictions - with indoor household meetings reducing to six people from two households.However she hopes there will still be a "reasonable degree of normality".The First Minister said: "This is similar to the situation we were at in mid September, as cases started to rise again but prevalence was still fairly low."" alt"East Lothian Courier: -day positive rate per , population " class"editor-image"-day positive rate per , population The First Minister said "Levels  and  are intended to apply at times such as now, when transmission is higher and rising."She said: ""Level  entails restrictions broadly similar to those currently in place just now outside the central belt ndash with limitations on hospitality and no gatherings in peoplersquos homes."Currentlypubs, bars, restaurants and cafes where in Scotland are only allowed to serve indoor customers between am and pm with a ban on alcohol inside, although alcoholic drinks can be served until pm in outdoor areas.Level  is broadly similar to the tougher restrictions which currently apply across the central belt, with much of hospitality being closed completely.Since October , bars and licensed restaurants in five health board areas ndash Greater Glasgow and Clyde, Lanarkshire, Ayrshire and Arran, Lothian and Forth Valley ndash have been forced to close for all but takeaways.Ms Sturgeon added: "There are however some key dferences ndash for example we envisage restaurants being able to open, at least partially, in Level ."Levels  and  are intended to apply for relatively short periods ot time to bring transmission under control."The First Minister said restrictions at Level  are "closer to a full lockdown", with things like non-essential shops being closed.She said: "We would not use [Level ] unless absolutely necessary ndash would apply when transmission rates are or threatening to become very high, with corresponding pressure on the NHS.""However even under level  restrictions,  people from up to  households could still meet outdoors there would be no limit on outdoor exercise for iniduals and manufacturing and construction businesses would stay open, with safety measures in place.""In other words, we do not envisage ing to a situation as severe as the first lockdown."" alt"East Lothian Courier: Positive cases in Scotland " class"editor-image"Positive cases in Scotland The First Minister said the "objective at all levis is,as far as possible, to keep schools open - though with necessary safety measures in place."That is in the best interests of children and young people."The First Minister says anoyone who is shielding should continue to follow the general public advice.However she added: "Todayrsquos publication also provides additional advice for each level of restrictions - for activities like going to work, school, shopping and having contact with others."You will find this advice in the framework itself, and the CMO is sending you a letter today."You can follow this advice to the letteryou want to. Howeveryou want to understand the evidence, and take informed decisions, we will shortly be publishing a guide to help you to do that."The First Minister also pointed people towards the National Helpline foradvice and support ndash the number is   ."Nicola Sturgeon says full details will appear on the gov.scot website today.

title: list-glasgow-shops-administration-lockdown
story: Here we look at some of the businesses who will no longer be operating in the city and the ones under threat.Remnant KingsCity location: Howard StreetA total of  stafflost their jobs from the firmrsquos bases in Glasgow, Hamilton, and Edinburgh after the administrators were called in.The firm, which started in Glasgow in , said that although they were historically profitable, they have since suffered from declining turnover and trading dficulties in recent years caused by changing consumer habits.:Glasgow firm Remnant Kings goes into admistration resulting in job lossesOasis and Warehouse GroupCity locations past and present: Buchanan Galleries, Silverburn, Princes Square, and Glasgow Fort.The company behind Oasis and Warehouse went into administration in April when Deloitte was appointed as administrator.All stores haveclosed indefinitely whileonline sales have stopped.Reports say the fashion brands have been sold to restructuring business Hilco in a deal which includes stock but not the  stores or  concessions.Hash Ladha, chief executive of Oasis Warehouse, previouslysaid: ldquoThis is a situation that none of us could have predicted a month ago, and comes as shocking and dficult news for all of us.ldquoWe as a management team have done everything we can to try and save the iconic brands that we love.:Oasis and Warehouse who have shops in Glasgow fall into administrationCath KidstonCity location: Gordon StreetCath Kidston said they will not reopen their shops when lockdown ends.They called in the administrators in April with the closure of shops costing around  jobs.It is understood that the owner of the retro fashion brand has secured a deal to buy back the brand and its online operation.
