title: Call for road improvements following serious accident
story: ROADS officials have been asked to carry out improvements at a section of the Downpatrick Road near Clough in the wake of an accident involving a Translink bus and a car last Friday morning.There have been a number of reported accidents at a sweeping bend in the road close to the village, with calls for improvements led by Slieve Croob councillor Alan Lewis.He said there have been several accidents in the same area over the past two months, urging the Department for Infrastructure to begin work immediately to improve road safety at what is one of the districtrsquos busiest roads.A number of pupils on board the bus were among several people taken to hospital following last Friday morningrsquos crash which resulted in part of the busy main road being closed for a number of hours as police conducted an extensive investigation into the circumstances of the collision.It is understood pupils from St Malachyrsquos High School were on the Translink service to Castlewellan when the accident occurred.Within minutes, emergency services rushed to the scene with paramedics, police officers and Fire and Rescue personnel joined by the crew of the air ambulance. Two people in the car and the driver of the bus were taken to hospital.Twelve pupils were on board the bus with two treated at the scene by paramedics with a third taken to hospital with non-le threatening injuries. The student was later discharged.Cllr Lewis mdash who attended the scene of the accident ndash said everyonersquos thoughts will be with all those involved.He said the crash took place at a sweeping bend which is often busy during the morning school run and revealed that there have been a number of recent accidents at this particular location.ldquoThis is something that the Department for Infrastructure should take a look at in terms of increasing safety, he continued.Cllr Lewis also praised everyone who assisted at last weekrsquos accident, including those who were first on the scene and members of the emergency services.He reserved special praise for the air ambulance, highlighting its continued commitment and dedication to the community, describing the service as ldquoabsolutely vital at this time of deep uncertainty.Cllr Lewis said he hoped all those injured in the accident will make a speedy recovery while Cllr Hugh Gallagher said the local community had been left in shock following last weekrsquos accident.He said what happened has hit everybody hard because the two teenagers in the car that was involved in the crash ldquoare lovely young guys.He continued: ldquoItrsquos the last thing anybody wanted. That road can be a slippery one at times and there have been a few accidents on it before.Cllr Gallagher also praised the quick response of the emergency services including the air ambulance. He said that once again the service ldquohad come up trumps by taking the most seriously injured teenager to the hospital.ldquoThey really did a fantastic job along with all the other emergency services, he added.Translink has confirmed it is working with the PSNI into finding out the circumstances of the accident.Police, who have issued a fresh appeal for information, are keen to hear from anyone who may have witnessed the accident or was travelling along the Downpatrick Road at the time and may have captured dashcam footage.They want to hear from anyone who may have seen the car before the collision with the bus and what the road conditions were like at the time.Anyone who can assist is asked to contact officers on the non-emergency  number, quoting reference    ..prettyPhoto

title: Camogs lift Ulster Intermediate title
story: A LATE burst of scoring from Down saw them snatch victory from the jaws of defeat in the Ulster Intermediate Camogie Championship final at Pearse Ogs, Armagh.Armagh had looked set to be crowned champions when they held a - to - lead after  minutes.However the Mourne girls rallied and went on to deservedly claimed a first ever provincial title at this level.Going into the match, Armaghrsquos main threat looked to come from players such as the Donnelly sisters, Rachel Merry and Ciara Hill. But Down had troopers who stood up to the challenge and excelled.Neisha McCullough was superb in thwarting the danger. As well as that, Lauren Clarke and Isabella OrsquoHare worked tirelessly for the cause and kept their opponents occupied throughout.Erin Rafferty and Olivia Boyle also battled stoically for Down and were instrumental in the teamrsquos superiority at the business end of this contest.Manager Derek Dunne was delighted with the overall performance. ldquoWe had a very young side out there, he said.ldquoNo one was over the age of , and to be honest that maybe showed a bit in the first half when we took the wrong option a few times.ldquoIn the second half we created a lot more chances, but it wasnrsquot really until close to the end that we made that count on the scoreboard.Dunne added that the result will do wonders for his team in the long run. ldquoI thought we worked the ball well right throughout that match. That was very good for such a young team without a lot in the way of challenge games for preparation.ldquoAnd lting the cup at the end, will push these girls on to the next level in terms of their confidence.Ciara Donnellyrsquos scoring had Armagh in the ascendancy in the first half, but Katie McGilligan fired to the back of the net to boost Downrsquos challenge. At half-time, the sides were level at - to -.Down made the brighter start to the second period, scoring three points in the opening ten minutes.However, Armagh were not to be shaken off so easily and a thumping goal from Ciara Donnelly put Armagh a point ahead, with Rachel Merry adding a minor score just before the water break.Another Merry score and a wonderfully-taken effort from Lianne Donnelly kept the Orchard countyrsquos noses in front.However a game-turning moment came on  minutes when Lauren Clarke found the net. Niamh Rodgers added a point as the clock ticked over into added time. Aoe McDowell pounced for a third Down goal to clinch victory for the ecstatic Red and Blacks.There was to be no double success for the county unfortunately. Despite the excellent Ciara Fitzsimmons netting a hat-trick of goals, Downrsquos U- camogs failed to reach the U- final in Randalstown on Sunday, falling to Antrim on a scoreline of - to -.Down scorers: L Clarke , A McDowell , K McGilligan , N McCullagh , M SloanI OrsquoHare , N Rodgers .Armagh scorers: C Donnelly , R Merry , L Donnelly , E OrsquoKane ..prettyPhoto

title: Dismay after cleaning told to stay out of schools
story: A LOCAL principal has criticised a decision not to have cleaning staff in schools over the two-week closure.All schools in the province closed their doors last Friday for a fortnight owing to the sharp rise in coronavirus cases.Mr Mark Morgan, principal of St Colmanrsquos High and Sixth Form College in Ballynahinch, said the announcement, without any reference to what he described as ldquoblended learning, had put principals on the back foot.ldquoThis is not what children need at this time, he said. ldquoFortunately, the teaching staff in St Colmanrsquos will continue working online with our students, but the holiday statement does not augur well considering the time lost to learning to date.On Friday the Education Authorityinformed schools that school cleaning staff need not report for work and will be paid as normal.ldquoGiven that this virus is spread through airborne transmission, surely to goodness this window of opportunity should be used to intensively sanitise all schools rather than again designating as a paid holiday, said Mr Morgan.He continued: ldquoOur school has been without hot water since the beginning of term in August. Despite constant promises from the EA and their contractors we are still no closer to getting this issue resolved.ldquoConsidering the number of our parents who will be losing their jobs during this crisis it is unconscionable that those being paid a regular salary are failing to deliver a service.On Friday Education Minister Peter Weir visited The High School in Ballynahinch where he opened a new ICT suite and met with staff and pupils.Mr Weir visited classrooms and spoke with the pupils, asking about how they were operating in bubbles.The board of governors and the principal, Mr Paul Marks, also had a chance for a meeting about the new mid-term arrangements and how this would affect the pupils.Mr Marks said afterwards: ldquoToday was a chance for the Minister of Education to see how schools are operating under Covid and the arrangements we have put in place to allow safe teaching and learning for our pupils.ldquoI am really pleased to have Minister Weir here as I got to show off just what a wonderful school we have and how great our children are. I am really proud of what we have achieved here and hope for even greater things to come.A number of other local principals have commented on the extended Halloween break.Mr Joe McCann, principal of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School in Downpatrick, said the timing of the closure would appear to be appropriate, given the rising number of Covid- cases throughout Northern Ireland.lsquoWe have been extremely busy to ensure that the school is a safe place for staff and pupils. We have tried to keep the school fully operational and have been working closely with the Public Health Agencyto deal with the cases that have presented, he remarked.ldquoWe would like to thank our parents for their patience and understanding in responding so promptly to communication from the school and PHA during these challenging times.ldquoI want to pay tribute to our students, particularly those taught in bubbles, who have coped admirably with the lsquonew normalrsquo. For our Key Stage  pupils, the break is welcome.Mr McCann continued: ldquoHowever, while the timing is right from a public health perspective, the Ministerrsquos announcement last Friday regarding exam arrangements, specically concerning GCSE Maths and GCSE English, has heightened anxiety among pupils, parents and staff as they work to prepare for an exam in January.ldquoI also want to pay tribute to my staff for their continued effort through what has been the most challenging time in their careers. Their work in creating a safe learning environment has been tremendous.Mrs Maud Perry, principal of Down High School, described the current situation as ldquoconcerning and hoped that the transmission of the virus will reduce as a result of this extended half-term.ldquoMy main hope is that everyone in the school community remains safe, she said. ldquoIt is important that all people in the district do their utmost to comply with regulations and act in a socially responsible way.ldquoThis has been an especially dficult start to the school year and I want to commend my colleagues for the very professional and dedicated way in which they have coped with a wholly dferent school experience.ldquoThere are many uncertainties at present, not least the situation in relation to public examinations. I hope the awarding bodies provide clear and helpful guidance to teachers, pupils and parents as a matter of urgency. The lack of clarity to date has heightened anxiety for young people, parents and teachers.Mrs Perry added: ldquoSchools have worked extremely hard to welcome pupils back to structured face-to-face learning experiences and pupils were thoroughly enjoying their school experience, albeit it very dferent.ldquoI really hope that we canto what we do best after this lsquocircuit breakerrsquo. Children do need to be in school for so many social, emotional and educational reasons and I hope that we canenergised on November .Mr Peter Dobbin, principal of Assumption Grammar School in Ballynahinch, also welcomed the extended Halloween break and said students deserved a ldquomuch-needed rest from the pressures of school le.He continued: ldquoThe mental impact of Covid- on our young people cannot be underestimated at this time and we need to look after them.ldquoNow is the time for students to breathe again and to look after themselves before ing to school on November . We would encourage all our young people to adhere to public health guidelines during this period.Mr Ciaran Maguire, principal of De La Salle High School in Downpatrick, said the school had adhered to official guidance to mitigate risk and keep everyone safe.ldquoWhile our pupils welcome and deserve the extended break for Halloween, it canrsquot be said for us as a school and for other schools in the community, who were preparing to continue teaching remotely, he said.Mr Maguire said that from next week, students would be encouraged to log on to continue their studies, ldquoirrespective of the Ministerrsquos advice.He continued: ldquoWe have allocated a large number of IT devices to enable our children to engage and we continue to source these devices to ensure no one misses out.Mr Maguire said thatschools could not reopen, Mr Weir should allow them to teach remotely.ldquoWhile there is nothing like face to face teaching, itrsquos the best option as opposed to a further extension to the break, he continued. ldquoSchools are under immense pressure to deliver content and prepare not only for GCSE GCE exams, but to educate children as a whole in a very tight window.ldquoI would welcome DE CCEA to look at this urgently, the current changes are not near enough. Children are anxious and worried. A bold decision needs to be made in respect to how schools prepared for exams.ldquoIt seems no one is listening to those people on the ground, in the classroom working with children, delivering two year programmes and trying to deal with Covid.Mr Maguire added: ldquoWe have a considerable number of pupils sitting GCSE science papers on their . They are not being prepared the way I want them to be prepared, how others previous to them were prepared. They are not getting a fair chance at this exam paper but yet weare told to continue aseverything is normal. Itrsquos not good enough.Mr Stephen Taylor, principal of Blackwater Integrated College in Downpatrick, expressed his concern about the loss of learning for students.However, he believed the welfare of all students and the wider community was the priority and the decision to close schools on the basis of medical advice was correct.ldquoIn Blackwater Integrated College during the past eight weeks much work has been done to ensure staff and students are set up for remote learning through Google Classroom for an eventuality such as this, he said.lsquolsquoWe have made sure all students have access to Google Classroom from home should this period of closure extend beyond the two weeks by lending out iPads to many students and working closely with students to ensure they have access to high quality online learning.He added: rsquorsquoBlackwater has been fortunate as a school that no member of the school community has tested positive since restart and I commend everyone associated with the college for their hard work in ensuring a safe environment for all.rsquorsquoMr Seamus Hanna, principal of St Colmcillersquos High School in Crossgar, said he recognised Covid- had greatly impacted on the entire school community.ldquoWe are determined to help all our pupils bridge the educational gap they have suffered since closing in March, whilst also supporting their emotional and social needs, he said.ldquoWe understand the frustration of families with schools closing but this decision is an attempt to keep all members of our school safe and avoid longer closures.ldquoOur Year  pupils are due to sit exams in the November series however, we have had no update from the Minister of Education on contingency plans. I am genuinely concerned as to what will happenwe do notin November ora pupil, or whole class, have to self-isolate.ldquoI am also frustrated at the Ministerrsquos response regarding the summer exams. The expectation to sit full GCSE courses in a number of subjects, including Maths, having missed face to face teaching for four months, places further pressure on pupils.ldquoOur pupils are important to all of us as iniduals, we know their hopes and aspirations and aim to help them achieve these. They are not simply another number or statistic.Mr Hanna continued: ldquoAs principal, I feel we are fighting not only the virus, but the decisions from the Minister of Education who, rather than supporting, is pushing against us. The gates of St Colmcillersquos may be closed for a while. However, we will continue to support all our pupils through online resources.ldquoWe have ensured all pupils have access to Google Classroom and online Maths programmes whilst providing tutorial videos to help our parents understand how pupils access these.He added: ldquoSt Colmcillersquos High School will continue to support all our pupils, parents and staff during and after this closure, working together to prioritise our pupils.Shimna Integrated College principal, Mr Kevin Lambe, said the school would be treating the two-week closure as a holiday.ldquoWe know our staff and students, especially Years  and  who have been back since August , are more than ready for a real rest, he said.ldquoOur support staff and premises staff have been back for even longer and teachers were working away preparing for this very strange year. The two weeks are holiday and schools will not be delivering remote learning.ldquoHowever, staff have shared with students ideas for good things to do during the circuit breaker and have provided guidance to help our examination year students to take the initiative and make good use of their time. Primarily we want out students to stay safe..prettyPhoto

title: Dog euthanasia to be discussed with animal charities and PSNI
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council is to consult with animal charities and the PSNI as part of a two-pronged approach to reduce the number of dogs put down each year.Recent figures published by the Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairsconfirmed that  dogs were put down by the council during the last financial year, with the figure accounting for over a third of the Northern Ireland total.The government department produces annual statistics to compare the number of dogs humanely destroyed by each council after straying, abandonment or dangerous behaviour. Province-wide, a total of  dogs were euthanised last year, with Ards and North Down Council the only local authority not to destroy any animals.Councils do not have powers to seize dogs from homes or euthanise legally dangerous animals without a court order, while people whose dog strays and is seized by a council dog warden could receive a warning or fixed penalty fine.Last week, local politicians supported a proposal to examine why the number of dogs the council destroys is so high, with the Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee agreeing that officials consult with both animal charities and local police.Councillors say they are keen for the PSNI to crack down on puppy farming and illegal breeding establishments.Rowallane councillor Patrick Brown said there should be ldquoextreme concern that substantially more dogs are put down in the local council area and is pleased that the local authority is to work with others to reduce the number of dogs it destroys after backing a motion he tabled on the issue.It urged council officials to consider ways they can bring together strategic partners such as dog wardens, local kennels, animal welfare officers, police and animal rescue charities to address the issue, including through tackling the illegal and unethical breeding and sale of dogs, particularly online.Cllr Brown described the number of dogs the local authority destroys as ldquoparticularly worrying considering the recent increase in dog theft and illegal puppy farms.He said while there are always situations where a dog may need to be put down due to ill health, efforts should be taken to keep the number of animals euthanised as low as possible.ldquoEven many old or aggressive dogs who are often put down can lead fulfilling lives under the right circumstances, usually with the help of specialist animal charities, continued Cllr Brown.ldquoUnfortunately, Newry, Mourne and Down Council sends less than five percent of its dogs to animal charities while in most other areas itrsquos between  and %. In addition, the local authority sells % of them to the public while in other areas itrsquos around %.Commending local dog kennels for finding homes for so many dogs, Cllr Brown believes that by working more closely with animal charities, the council could reduce the number of unwanted dogs and subsequently the number that are put down.ldquoI am pleased that the council can begin to work strategically to find a forever home for every dog possible, regardless of age or disposition, and am pleased that officials will consult with animal charities on how the number of dogs euthanised can be reduced, he said, also welcoming a commitment to work with police to halt puppy farming and illegal breeding establishments.Cllr Brown said he was also concerned that many other local councils in Northern Ireland had not claried why figures for the number of dogs they destroy are so low.He added: ldquoI am worried there is a lack of transparency in how some councils report their numbers as many did not write back to Newry, Mourne and Down Council when asked for clarity on how they manage unwanted dogs. Whilst this doesnrsquot excuse our districtrsquos overly high figures, it does bring into question why other areas are so low.ldquoI would like to see all un-homed dogs who are healthy enough not to be put down found a home, eventhat is with a specialist charity which can deal with dangerous or aggressive animals. I hope to see progress and a reduction in the number of dogs euthanised in our area in the months ahead and I look forward to working with the council to achieve this..prettyPhoto

title: Down hurlers’ victory over Derry secures promotion
story: FOR several years, Down have made it to the door of NHL Division A, only to miss out on entry at the final stage.However on Sunday, they finally gained promotion courtesy of victory over Derry at the Athletic Grounds, Armagh.Down boss Ronan Sheehan and his charges have come so close in recent times, without taking that final step.On Sunday, all that was forgotten, as they got their hands on the cup and the ticket to the higher stage.ldquoTo finally get over the line means everything, Sheehan beamed afterwards. ldquoWe made a big decision this weekend in the U-s when we didnrsquot play Phelim Savage and Ronan Costello.ldquoThat was probably what proved to be the dference today. They proved here A is where they really want to be.ldquoA lot of credit must go to Sean Og McAteer and and Jack Devaney for that performance. They put up a fantastic senior club championship this year, brilliantly structured and the boys came back to the county squad in great shape.ldquoSo I would like to pay tribute to what our four senior clubs have done for the lads. This victory is as much about them as it is about us. Hopefully all the clubs in the intermediate and the juniors will reap the benefits of this promotion in the next number of years.A big factor in Downrsquos success in this encounter was the performance of the Sands brothers, Eoghan and Daithi.Their perpetual motion display and sharpness saw them land - of Downrsquos overall total between them.Eoghan found the back of the net after just  minutes and gave Down the lead for the first time after the Oak Leaf county led through scores from Cormac Doherty and Eamonn Magill.The sides were level twice in the first half. However, Down edged in front - to - at the break with Oisin McManus and Daithi Sands on target.Downrsquos tactics were simple, but effective mdash overload the defence to smother any Derry attack and then go long to the Sands brothers to let them do their damage.When Pearse Og McCrickard struck the second goal ten minutes from the end, Down were on their way to an ultimately comfortable progression to Division A and victory in this final as they took home the silverware.Down: S Keith, T Murray, C Taggart, M Hughes, B Trainor, C Woods , L Savage, M Conlon, P Savage , R Costello, P Og McCrickard, , D Hughes, O McManus , E Sands , D SandsSubs: R McCusker for Costello at H T, T Prenterfor McManus , M Fisher for Hughes , D Mallon for Murray ..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C October 25%2C 2000
story: SAINTFIELD mdash A local fire chief who plucked a Saintfield woman from her blazing home last weekend is to be recommended for a bravery award.Graham Crossett rescued the frightened woman, who was trapped in the upstairs of her Listooder Park home after a fire broke out on Saturday morning.Police probing the early morning attack believe the fire was started deliberately and say the bravery of the local fire officer almost certainly saved the womanrsquos le.They have also confirmed thatshe had not survived the attack on her two-storey home, they would have launched a murder inquiry.The modest fire officer who has been branded a hero by people in the Listooder Park area, says he did what anyone  would have done.When he arrived at the womanrsquos home she was trapped in her bedroom as choking black smoke engulfed the stairway, preventing her escape.Mr Crossett, who was the duty officer for the area last weekend, raced to the scene of the blaze ahead of local fire crews and as he did so, a fire officer based in Lisburn talked to the woman on the telephone in a bid to keep her calm and assure her help was on the way.He said: ldquoI managed to alert some neighbours and one of them was able to get me a ladder which I then climbed up to help lower the woman to safety before she was taken to the Downe Hospital.DOWNPATRICK mdash Highly dangerous illegal fireworks circulating in the area could kill or cause serious injury, Downpatrickrsquos police chief has warned.Superintendent Brendan McGuigan, has this week confirmed that teenagers across the district are gaining access to a proleration of dangerous fireworks, many of which do not meet current safety standards.The police chiefrsquos warning comes a matter of days after a post box at the Saul Road in Downpatrick was blown apart by a lethal banger, believed to have been imported from Germany.The device was placed inside the box by three teenagers who were spotted running away and when the banger exploded, large chunks of metal and letters were hurled into the air.Mr McGuigan confirmed police believe the fireworks are finding their way into the district through a iety of sources and revealed the majority of those being sold do not meet current British safety standards.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Regeneration officials in Ballynahinch have this week claimed a major new planning document backs their campaign for the construction of a bypass around the town.They are convinced the so-called draft issues paper, which has been produced to help formulate the new areas plan for Down District, makes it clear that Ballynahinch has a greater need than Downpatrick for a bypass.They are still seething at Down Councilrsquos decision to push for by-passes for both towns, a move they believe is tantamount to disaster and will almost certainly result in both schemes never being constructed.However, the publication of the new planning paper has given them renewed hope because it makes it quiet clear that while a by-pass is not the answer to Downpatrickrsquos traffic problems, it can make a major contribution to log-jammed streets and endless miles of tail backs in Ballynahinch,LOUGHINISLAND mdash Down councillors have called for a meeting with Loughinisland residents to solve a dispute about the villagersquos play area.Recently erected goalposts adjacent to Loughview Cottages have proved controversial with some councillors claiming they have the backing of residents and others saying residents are opposed.At Monday nightrsquos client services committee meeting, Mr Billy Alexander claimed he had received numerous objections to the goalposts.Mr Alexander said he had been contacted by three families who felt the posts were too close to houses lining the field.Calling for an immediate consultation regarding the play area, he said the older children were now attracted to the kick about area and this was also bothering residents.However, Mr Patsy Toman said the family who lived closest to the goal posts were ldquototally supportive of them, and he said children in the area would be forced to cross the main roadthey were removed.DUNDRUM mdash Dundrum could have its own Christmas lights this year. Residents who attended the village committeersquos annual meeting last week were told that festive lights could be erected on telegraph poles this Christmas.Also during the well attended meeting it was revealed the past  months have been very successful with a number of important events, including the Millennium Festival in August.It was also confided that further cross-community events are planned, including a childrenrsquos Christmas party.The village committeersquos outgoing chairman, Mrs Frances Flynn, thanked everyone who provided help and sponsorship for the summer event, including Down Council, local business people and Newcastle RUC.It was also reported that the villagersquos Thursdayrsquos Club, which is attended by senior citizens, also had a busy year, with ious outings. The group also secured funding from a Help the Aged Millennium Award, with the cash used to purchase craft goods.PORTAFERRY mdash Portaferry Integrated Primary School will come alive with colour this weekend with the launch of a bright flower festival to mark the official opening of a pound, extension.Fresh floral displays have been carefully chosen to decorate the school this week as a colourful background to celebrations of the brand new extension.New office accommodate, staff room, storage and resource areas will be officially opened in the school on Monday afternoon by education chiefs from the Northern Ireland Council for Integrated Education and the South Eastern Education and Library Board, ending months of hard work.The flower festival, organise with the assistance of the Portaferry Flower club and local florist Monica Galloway, was specially planned to coincide with the opening by school principal Jenner Smyth.NEWCASTLE mdash Celebrity television chef Jenny Bristow will visit Newcastle next week to take part in a fundraising cookery demonstration.The Slieve Donard Hotel event on November  will help raise money for Cancer Research and Multiple Sclerosis.Jenny, the author of six best selling cookery books, will host the demonstration which will have a distinctly festive flavour.CROSSGAR ndash A local man was crowned champion at this weekrsquos th annual Northern Ireland Ploughing Championships.Crossgarrsquos David Gill fought off stf competition from across the British Isles to win the title and book a place at the world championships in Denmark next year.David will be joined in the th world championships by runner-up David Wright from Magherafelt.Last year David finished third in the world championship and is hoping that this year he will go one better.KILLINCHY mdash A Killinchy man has been given the means to put his passion for one of the worldrsquos oldest crafts to good use.Daniel Dorman has been awarded a Queen Elizabeth scholarship worth pound, to help him study shipbuilding at the International Boat Building Training College in Lowestoft.Daniel is no stranger to the seas. Already the  year-old has achieved five Royal Yachting Association qualications.He spent  months cruising the Mediterranean and the seas around North and Central America while working abroad the worldrsquos largest sailing yacht.Daniel spent time in Antigua restoring a  Hong Kong cutter and in Trinidad restoring a -feet yacht built in  before ing to Ireland to carry out general boat repairs. He has also restored his own boat which he sails on Strangford Lough..prettyPhoto

title: Hotel boss: We can’t go on like this
story: A LOCAL hotelier has warned that the hospitality industry is facing the biggest challenge in her letime.All hotels, restaurants and pubs were ordered closed their doors on Friday for four weeks as a result of though new coronavirus restrictions.Itrsquos the second lockdown the sector has experienced since March and it is feared that some establishments will not reopen.Gertie McCaugherty, general manager of the Millbrook Lodge Hotel in Ballynahinch, said: ldquoI have worked in hospitality all my le. I fear for the industrythe current lockdown is extended.Equally concerned is Stephen Magorrian, co-owner of Denvirrsquos Coaching Inn in Downpatrick, who warned of ldquocarnagevenues were not allowed to reopen in December.Under the new restrictions announced by the Northern Ireland Executive the entire hospitality sectors is closed apart from food deliveries and takeaways.Speaking yesterday, Mrs McCaugherty said it was a ldquovery stressful time for owners, staff and customers.ldquoItrsquos a case of here we go again. I know itrsquos nobodyrsquos fault, but we canrsquot keep going on like this, she said. ldquoWe were due to hold a wedding reception here today, but it had to be cancelled. To be told the previous Friday that you canrsquot have your wedding is just dreadful.ldquoWe have had to move dates for other weddings, but we will lose a signicant amount of business.Mrs McCaugherty said all of the Millbrookrsquos  full and part-time staff were currently being furloughed, apart from some administrative staff.ldquoWe are a family run hotel and one of the biggest employers in Ballynahinch. We try to look after our staff and treat them like a family. I appreciate how dficult it must be for them.ldquoThis is a bigger blow to them than the lockdown in March. They canrsquot believe it is happening again.Mrs McCaughtery said the hospitality industry was being unfairly treated compared with other sectors of the economy.ldquoI think there is a sprinkling of unfairness in all of this, she continued. ldquoWhy, for example, can you go into a shop and move around the place, but are not permitted to come into a pub or restaurant and have something to eat or drink ldquoWe have done everything that was required of us and more. Before we reopened in July we put in sanitising stations and observed correct distancing all the other guidelines. We went above and beyond what was asked.ldquoBusiness was good after the reopening. We had lots of staycations and overnight stays. The East Out to Help Out in August proved busy, as it was for our sister hotel, the Ivanhoe, in Carryduff.ldquoWe introduced live outdoor music, which people enjoyed even in slightly cold weather. People need to be together and are providing more than just food and drink.Mrs McCaugherty praised the support offered by Hospitality Ulster and the Northern Ireland Hotels Federation, which, she said, could not have been more helpful.She was also hopeful of better times ahead. ldquoThis is definitely the most challenging time I can remember. But have worked and lived through the Troubles and I am confident we can get through this, she said.ldquoNext year is building up to be busy, which is great. We have to be positive.Mr Magorrian said the closure was ldquodisappointing but somewhat understandable given the rise in the number of Covid- cases.However, he warned that the industry could not survive many more lockdowns.He said the current closure was more dangerous than the one earlier in the year because of changes in the Governmentrsquos furloughing scheme, which would place a greater demand on employers meeting the cost of staff wages.ldquoI hope that everyone sticks to the guidelines this time. It is essential that everyone does their bit so that we can open for business in December and over Christmas, he said.ldquoIf we do not get that business then it will be carnage in January and many establishments will not survive. An extended lockdown would be catastrophic.Mr Magorrian said he is concerned about the future of some so-called lsquowetrsquo pubs which do not serve food and were only permitted to reopen a few weeks ago.ldquoWe were able to open in July and that brought some money in. But the wet pubs have only been open a few weeks. I fear for themthey do not get some business in.Mr Magorrian said all  staff at Denvirrsquos, which is part of the Horatio Group, were currently furloughed.ldquoOur staff are our number one priority, but we are at the mercy of the Government. There is nothing we can do. We need the Governmentrsquos support.He added: ldquoThis is nobodyrsquos fault, but people need to take the situation seriously..prettyPhoto

title: Leisure centre to be lit up blue for 75th anniversary of United Nations
story: DOWN Leisure Centre in Downpatrick will be illuminated with blue lighting next month to mark the th anniversary of the UnitedNations.Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairwoman Laura Devlin will throw the switch on November  to commemorate the signing of the UN Charter in San Francisco in .Soon after the end of the Second World War, nations across the globe decided to change the course of history and took the commitment to work together for peace. Five years ago, Newry, Mourne and Down Council highlighted the th anniversary of the UN and accepted a commemorative copy of the UN Charter.Cllr Devlin says she is delighted to illuminate Down Leisure Centre blue to commemorate the th Anniversary of the establishment of the United Nations.ldquoBy lighting up the building we are celebrating the humanitarian and peace keeping efforts undertaken by the UN throughout the world since its inception in , she continued, explaining that she is looking forward to the event.ldquoThe work of the United Nations and its member states is critical to help address the many challenges and issues that face us all in todayrsquos world.ldquoI would like to take this opportunity to thank the United Nations Association of Northern Irelandbranch for the work they do to highlight the goals of the UN..prettyPhoto

title: Lidl store proposal committee meeting
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee meets today to discuss a plannersrsquo recommendation to approve a new poundm supermarket in Newcastle.Leading retailer Lidl plans to redevelop the former St Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo Primary School site in the town with the proposal including a new pound, base for the Mourne Mountain Rescue Team.Outline planning permission is being sought to demolish the former school building to pave the way for the new store and rescue centre and parking for  vehicles.Plans to redevelop the former primary school site mdash which is expected to create up to  new jobs mdash were originally submitted in January  to replace Lidlrsquos existing base at Railway Street in the resort.Last November, it was announced that planning permission for the multi-million pound store was to be quashed following a judicial review by objectors. It was confirmed at the time that permission was quashed as the result of a procedural error in relation to the papers before the local authorityrsquos Planning Committee.A new pedestrian crossing at the Bryansford Road junction with Shimna Road forms part of the proposal, with Lidl consistently arguing that its current base is too small to allow the store to carry the companyrsquos full range of goods, highlighting issues with narrow aisles and inadequate parking provision.The store argues the Railway Street base was only supposed to be a temporary home until a larger unit could be found.Lidl says it has been looking for an alternative town centre site for over decade without success until the Shanslieve Drive site became available, with the planned mountain rescue team centre providing the volunteers with a permanent base.Planners have confirmed that they have received a number of objections about the proposed new development with those concerned arguing that the proposal is not in keeping with the residential nature of the area.In addition, they claim that the closure of the existing Lidl store will have a detrimental impact on Newcastle town centre and surrounding inconvenience stores.Concern has also been expressed about the proposed storersquos impact on traffic, the potential for increased flooding and the impact of selling alcohol, particularly to young children, with objectors also arguing that Lidlrsquos proposal is contrary to planning policy, is not in the interests of the community and will impact on the residential amenity of Shanslieve Driveresidents.Recommending that the new supermarket should be granted outline approval, planners say its their opinion that the proposal is acceptable, having assessed it against planning policy and taking into account the input of consultees.Conditions attached to the outline approval recommendation include the net retail floorspace of the new store shall not exceed , square metres and that no goods or merchandise will be stationed or displayed in the forecourt.Opening hours are limited to am to pm from Monday to Saturday and from pm to pm on Sundays.Store deliveries are not permitted between pm and am with onsite floodlighting only operational between these hours.Planners are insisting thatoutline approval is granted at todayrsquos meeting, no development activity or demolition work, ground preparation or vegetation clearance can take place until a final construction and environmental management plan has been submitted and approved by the Planning Authority..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle Lions street collection raises £500 for diabetes charity
story: A COLLECTION organised by Newcastle Lions Club on Saturday raised almost pound for charity.Newcastle Lions would like to thank everyone who donated and stress that all the money will be going to a designated charity.Newcastle Lions, and other Lions clubs throughout Ireland, have been targeting the problem of diabetes this year.World Diabetes Day takes place on November  and last Tuesday Dr Kieran Walshe spoke of his personal journey with type  diabetes.He said that it had taken  years since insulin was first discovered for it to be delivered safely.Today, due to advances in bio technology, patients are controlling their blood glucose using a glucose sensor and a Bluetooth-enabled insulin pump from an algorithm on their mobile phones.Although this is a good news story much more needs to be done as the incidence of diabetes is increasing in both the developed and underdeveloped world. Diabetes the eighth biggest cause of death in the world.Type  diabetes occurs when the body stops producing enough insulin, or the produced insulin does not work properly. It is managed by healthy eating, regular physical activity and medication, which may include insulin injections.A spokesperson for Newcastle Lions Club said: ldquoNewcastle Lions are committed to playing their part in this work and the help and support of the local community in this very worthwhile project is greatly valued..prettyPhoto

title: Quoile River could boost district tourism economy
story: DOWNPATRICKrsquoS Quoile River has the capacity to become a major tourist attraction, according to two local councillors.Patrick Brown and Dermot Curran believe that investing in the waterway can attract more coarse anglers which in turn will boost the local economy.Given the latest coronavirus restrictions announced last week by the Northern Ireland Executive, angling is one sport that is not affected, with waterways easily able to accommodate social distancing requirements.Last week, Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee rejected a proposal to explore potential funding sources to stock the river, given the importance of coarse fishing to tourism and the economy.They agreed to leave restocking to the Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairswith the decision expected to be ratied at next monthrsquos full meeting of the council.A proposal tabled earlier this year by Cllr Brown urged the council to investigate funding sources to restock the Quoile and carry out a review of course fisheries across the district, while working with the government department and other local authorities to develop a best practice approach.Council officials confirmed at last weekrsquos meeting that they have been in contact with DAERA in relation to the requirements, regulations and legal requirements involved in restocking the Quoile and other rivers across the district.Government officials say that the Quoile is a natural river system that continues to have migrations of salmon, sea trout and eels and is recognised as an internationally important wetland for conservation.It says any proposal to add to existing stocks would require a series of surveys and assessments that have not yet been carried out, with this not currently seen as a departmental priority when the focus is on preparations for the EU Transition and Northern Ireland Protocol.Previously, anglers have expressed dismay at fish stock levels in the Quoile and believe that government officials pay greater attention to rivers in other parts of Northern Ireland.Cllr Brown said he was ldquovery disappointed that members of the council committee decided not to allocate any council budget to restocking the Quoile when they met last week.He said while restocking is primarily DAERArsquos responsibility, he suggested the government department has been ldquovery slow in fulfilling it, explaining that was the reason for his motion.ldquoArmagh, Banbridge and Craigavon Council spends over pound, a year restocking Loughgall River and, as a result, it is one of the most successful course fisheries in Ireland, bringing in a signicant amount to the local economy in the process, the councillor continued.ldquoThe council could have decided to allocate a modest amount toward restocking the Quoile to help bring it back to its former glory and even work in partnership with DAERA to fund this. Instead, the committee asked the government department to carry out restocking which it has thus far failed to do.Cllr Curran believes that a restocked river, in tandem with enhanced angling facilities, would attract local, national and international anglers.He says the river is a key tourism asset but has not had signicant amounts of money invested in it over recent years, suggesting that the waterway has the potential to become of the key jewels in the districtrsquos tourism crown.ldquoThe Quoile offers so much potential and there is much scope to invest in this fantastic facility, Cllr Curran continued.He added: ldquoAngling is very much part of the tourism offering in South Down. It is an important recreational sport and the Downpatrick river could be transformed with more investment and restocking.It is not beyond the realms of possibility that at some point in the future it could host a major angling competition. How great would that be for Downpatrick and the wider angling community..prettyPhoto

title: Raymond closes down the shutter
story: RAYMOND Ross, founder of Ardglass Videos, has decided to retire as video provider at all local point-to-point meetings and those he covered in the South.Raymond first started to video horse racing when he was the only cameraman covering racing first at Downpatrick and then at Down Royal, this being prior to the days of live television.Having previously concentrated on weddings on Saturdays and Sundays, Raymond started covering point-to-points in  and as he says he saw many parts of the country he would have not seen otherwise.I first started to travel to point-to-points with Raymond in the late s. The first one was a meeting near Dublin.It turned out to be an awful day, wet and windy.Since then we made trips to meetings in Wicklow, Meath, Westmeath, Kildare, Louth and where. We also made the journeys together to the majority of all the local meetings.In the early days it was just the two of us but in later years Raymondrsquos son, Kevin, and we Kathleen became regulars as orders for videos and DVDs came in thick and fast.Looking back, it would be hard to recall how many times we had to suffer long waits to get towed out of fields on wet days and of course there were days when we were also towed in.At times Raymond would travel to cover meetings at the likes of Durrow and I would drive to the local meeting with Kevin and Kathleen.We had some great times together finding new venues. It has been a long journey and many will miss Raymond at meetings in the future. No doubt he will also miss the craic with the many friends he made along the way.He may still do the odd meeting in the future but I will miss his regular phone call on race days checkingI would be going. Happy retirement Raymond and no more getting soaked, like at the recent Westmeath meeting.Raymond says he met lovely people over years, some of them, such as Peggy Hagan and Billy Vance, sadly no longer with us..prettyPhoto

title: Sporting wipeout
story: THE latest coronavirus restrictions have virtually wiped out all competitive sport across the district.None of the major sports have emerged unscathed and while GAA games were allowed to proceed, Downrsquos scheduled National Football League clash against Leitrim in Newry last Saturday was cancelled at the eleventh hour with the visitors deciding against heading north due to a number of factors, including travel restrictions.Other high profile casualties of the so-called circuit breaker measures announced last Friday were last Saturdayrsquos Harry Clarke and Bobby Dalzell Cup soccer finals.Celtic Bhoys and Ballynagross were due to contest the Harry Clarke final, while Killough and Ballynahinch Olympic Town were scheduled to battle for the Bobby Dalzell Cup. Both finals were due to take place at Ballyhornan.This weekend, the Newcastle League season was due to finally get underway, while there is still no start date for the Amateur League.Elsewhere, the districtrsquos rugby and hockey programme has been suspended with hopes that players canto action in mid-November.Ballynahinch Rugby Club was preparing to face Rainey Old Boys last Saturday in the Energia Community Series but had to abort their plans at short notice due to the new guidelines, while Ballynahinch and Saintfield hockey clubs had their respective league games cancelled.Down GAA chairman, Jack Devaney, said he was disappointed that last Saturdayrsquos game against Leitrim was called off at short notice, given the effort to make Pairc Esler and the game safe, in accordance with Covid regulations.ldquoWe didnrsquot know until late on Friday night that the game was off and that is really disappointing and frustrating, he said.ldquoWe had put in place every possible requirement in relation to the Covid restrictions for both sides to ensure that everyone who came to the ground, and it would have been very small numbers anyway, would have been safe to do so.ldquoIt was a late call and it was out of our hands and our control. We now have to focus on next week. I know that the lads and the whole team were very much set for Saturdayrsquos game and were very disappointed to get that call.The Down chairman revealed the first the county knew the game was off was on Friday evening, explaining that Leitrim GAA said it had no other choice other than to abandon their plans to play the game in Newry.In a statement, Leitrim GAA said that unfortunately, due to the greater health situation that has gripped the country, it found itself having to concede the Allianz League encounter.ldquoA number of players were awaiting test results and were unavailable to travel and other factors prevented further players from being available. Considering this greater health situation and in this course of action, we must respect this situation, the statement continued.It added: ldquoWe are unable to field a team. We are living through very dficult times in an ever-increasing pandemic situation. Leitrim GAA is acutely aware of the efforts that have been made to get the inter-county season up and running. However, on this occasion, we cannot fulfil this fixture, which is regrettable.Irish FA chief executive, Patrick Nelson, said the organisationrsquos priority is and has always been theof football mdash both training and matches mdash in a safe and responsible manner, confirming that it will continue to work with stakeholders across the game to meet that objective.ldquoIn light of the government announcement, we are reviewing our Covid- protocols and awaiting guidance from Sport Ireland and will issue an update as soon as possible, the IFA confirmed in a statement.ldquoAdditional restrictions will come into effect from midnight tonight and all clubs can train within current restrictions until then in socially distant pods of .The Irish Rugby Football Union confirmed that the Energia Community Series is no longer exempt from level three training and match restrictions.As a result, games in all four provinces have been suspended with immediate effect until further notice, with all clubs in level three and four areas now restricted to lsquonon-contact training onlyrsquo in pods of up to .For local sports clubs and the communities they serve, these are incredibly dficult times as they head into the winter months with hopes that at some stage soon, competitive matches can resume..prettyPhoto

title: Temporary staff wanted for Census 2021
story: THE Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency NISRA has launched its recruitment campaign for Census .Almost , temporary field staff will be required to help with census operations throughout Northern Ireland.If you are a people person, have great customer service skills and want to be part of something that affects all of us, then take a look to see how you can get involved in your area.The census takes place once every ten years and is a count of our population and housing.Itrsquos the largest and most complex statistical exercise undertaken in Northern Ireland and provides a benchmark on the size of our population.Census statistics are also used by central and local government, health providers, academia, commercial businesses and others to develop policies and plan services.The next census is planned for March , , and will be managed by the Census Office within the Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency .NISRA is seeking to recruit Census Enumerators across Northern Ireland. These are temporary appointments from February March to May .As an Enumerator, you will work from home and carry out enumeration duties in your allocated Enumeration District .The main focus of the role will be following up with all households from which a census form has not been received. This role is key in ensuring the success of Census .A detailed job deion can be found at www.nicsrecruitment.org.uk.You can also find out more on our social channels ndash Twitter: @NISRA or Facebook: https:www.facebook nisra.gov.uk.Census Enumerators will be employed on a fee pay basis and receive a total fee payment of pound, .Completed application forms must be ed no later than  noon on Friday, October , .For more information and to apply, visit: www.nicsrecruitment.org.uk..prettyPhoto

title: Waterworth nets three
story: CROSSGAR hitman Andrew Waterworth began the new Irish Premiership season with a bang on Saturday.His hat-trick helped champions Linfield open up their defence of the title with a - thumping of Carrick Rangers at Windsor Park.Speaking after the game, Waterworth said he aims to sharpen his game this season even more.ldquoI need to be a bit more ruthless, he said with a statement that will strike fear into defenders across the Irish League this season. ldquoOver the past couple of games, I think I have probably been actually trying a bit too hard to score the goals. I was a little bit more patient in the game with Carrick.ldquoWhen Nav [Navid Nasseri] cut down from the left for my third goal, I would usually have been busting to get into the six yard box, but instead I hung back and when the ball came in, I tried to direct away the goalkeeper as much as I could.ldquoThe first two goals were really well-worked. Kirk Millar and Conor Pepper combined well down the right for both. Conor played the ball exactly where it needed to be for my second.Waterworth said with football having been missing from local fansrsquo for so long, the Blues were keen to put on a show last weekend.ldquoThe fans havenrsquot seen any action at Windsor for a long time, so we wanted to perform well here. Irsquom playing in a really good team and getting plenty of chances.There are four of us playing for that number nine position. I probably could have scored more because some good deliveries came in.ldquoWith a little bit more conviction I could have come out with a few more. Irsquoll not be too hard on myself but.The early signs for this season once more bode ominously for the Blues rivals in the battle to land the Gibson Cup once more. However Waterworth thinks they can get even better.ldquoWe are good when we keep the ball and play through teams. Carrick are a tough team to play against, but we gave them the chance to grow into the game.ldquoWe worked hard to establish the early lead and I donrsquot know whether some of us took the foot off the gas a bit after that.It is something we must recty going forward but. We canrsquot afford to do that, because teams will hurt us.ldquoThere is no question we became complacent once we went two up. We were not picking up second balls, and they began to hurt us so that is a lesson.The Bluesrsquo Killyleagh-born manager, David Healy, paid tribute to evergreen Waterworth after his match-winning feat.ldquoAndy does that. He pops up in the right areas, and again Andyrsquos goal ratio over the last three, four, five years since I have been here has been just incredible.ldquoI think actually in that time, his all-round game has improved in the last  months to two years.Hopefully we can keep adding goals to Andyrsquos tally here.Waterworth will hope to keep his great start to the season going when the champions go to former boss David Jeffreyrsquos Ballymena United in the Danske Bank Premiership this Saturday.The former Northern Ireland U- international, who previously had spells at Ards, Lisburn Distillery, Hamilton Academicals and Glentoran, first came to prominence during a successful spell in the Amateur League with Kilmore Rec.The striker scored the opening two goals on Saturday after he got on the end of crosses supplied by Conor Pepper.A Caolan Loughran penalty for Rangers reduced the gap to - at half-time. Carrickrsquos Mark Surgenor was given his marching orders, with Jimmy Callacher making it - soon after.Ryan McGivern headed home the fourth, before -year old Waterworth completed his treble to ensure he would have the match ball.It was the second meeting of the sides of the week after the Blues had earlier won - away to Rangers in the County Antrim Shield..prettyPhoto

title: Young people recognised at annual service
story: FIRST Spa Boysrsquo Brigade held their annual Enrolment Service on Sunday in Spa Presbyterian Church.The service was conducted by the Rev David Hyndman, chaplain of the BB company and minister of the church.A select number of officers and boys who took part in the service were present in the church, while the rest of the company joined the service online using the videoconference , Zoom.The company captain, Dr Robert Whan, spoke about how it had not been possible to hold a display at the end of the last sessionback in March due to the Covid- lockdown.Badges and other prizes were distributed to the boys in September through socially distanced visits carried out by the officers.Among these were Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Awards to Ryan Graham, Jamie Ferguson and Jamie McNeill, and Gold Duke of Edinburgh Awards to Matthew Graham, Matthew McAdam and Scott McCaw.Dr Whan also referred to the success that the Anchor Boys had during the last session, winning both the Down Battalion and NI District indoor sports competitions with a team comprising Alexander Chambers, Jake Kelly, James McBride and Nevin Sulwinska, who were supported by Cole Gunda and Charlie Rodgers.Other prizes that should have been presented at the Display were as follows:Anchor Boys: Best Boy mdash James McBride.Junior Section: Do This Do That Throughout the Year mdash Reuben Forde ure Cup mdash Sam Boyd Best New Recruit mdash Adam Connolly Endeavour Cup mdash Cameron Gordon and Freddy Harris Promotion Cup mdash Lee Hunter and Jack Patterson Best Boy Cup mdash Lewis Ingram and Timmy Rodgers.Company and Senior Section: Drill Down Throughout the Year mdash Craig Gunda Junior Scripture mdash Ben Spiers Senior Scripture mdash Rhodri Phillips Endeavour Cup mdash Jack Connolly Best Junior Boy mdash Ben Spiers Best Senior Boy mdash Rhys Phillips and David Williamson Senior Badgework Shield mdash Jamie McNeill.At Sundayrsquos enrolment service a shield and certicate were presented to Oliver Kelly for winning the   Northern Ireland District P colouring competition, which was on Moses receiving the Ten Commandments on Mount Sinai.A special video message from Mervyn Murdock was played, congratulating the Anchor Boys on their NI District successes.The captain of st Raffrey BB company, Mervyn is president of the BBrsquos Down Battalion and Vice-President of the Boysrsquo Brigade in the UK and Republic of Ireland.It has not yet been possible for the boys of Spa company toto face-to-face meetings in the Arnold Hall, but the dferent sections of the company have been meeting for an adapted programme, using Zoom, since the start of October..prettyPhoto

title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. Growing up, his dad had more than one knocking about the yard – with Aaron himself all too keen to get into the driving seat any chance he could get.As he grew up, the interest in tractors remained – and he wasn’t just looking the top range vehicles, vintage was just as cool. title: covid  stats not available local areas wales
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityFor months the Welsh Government and PHW have been fielding criticism for not providing more localised statistics to help people frame a better understanding of the pandemicrsquos impact on Wales.The UK Government has published signicantly more localised data than Wales.Currently PHW only publishes the number of cases by local authority area.But some of Walesrsquo local authorities are geographically very large and figures therefore are unlikely to show an accurate picture.PHW does share the information on sub-local authority areas with the Welsh Government and local authorities to better inform localised responses to outbreaks, but it has been reported that due to a lack of capacity at PHW, it is impossible for that data to be produced in an appropriate and understandable format for public consumption.The intention is to develop a new map which will give more local information. While a date has not been confirmed, it is hoped this will be done in the coming weeks.Dr Giri Shankar explained: ldquoThe surveillance team produces timely and accurate reports which can be easily interpreted by incident management teams, local authorities, health boards and Welsh Government - and the data is used to make decisions quickly.ldquoThe demand placed on our surveillance team has grown considerably throughout the pandemic.ldquoWhile there are technical reasons why we refrain from producing sub-local reports, in general, the more granular the data is, the less valid the results will be.ldquoWhere there are a low number of cases in a given locality, publishing this data could have an unintended consequences of risk of deductive disclosure, or put simply, iniduals who have tested positive for COVID- may be identiable.ldquoOur intention is to develop Middle Super Output Area maps which will give more local information."At the moment, however, we are prioritising reports to local authority and health board Incident Management Teams to inform their local decision making."In the last week some councils across Wales have begun publishing their own localised data online to better inform residents. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: penarth singer voice weekend shares journey
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityRichie Gooding, who moved his le to Hamburg in the north of the country after getting married to native Phil last year, will have a blind audition on The Voice Germany.While nothing can be given away on whether Richie made it through to the live quarter-finals, he has taken the chance to share his thoughts on the challenges facing the music industry, growing up gay in Penarth, and trading the seaside town he adores for Hamburg.ldquoI grew up in Penarth and lived there until I was , he began. ldquoI went to Victoria Primary School and then onto Stanwell School, where I really started to find myself.ldquoSince I can remember I had a passion for musical theatre. Thatrsquos what I spent my time doing ndash as well as drinking cider on the benches at Alexandra Park!Picture: Christoph LehnerRichie grew up in a sport-loving household. Dad Mike is the president of Penarth Athletic Club and brother Paul remains a rugby-nut.ldquoI couldnrsquot think of much worse than rugby when I was a kid, he laughed. ldquoMusic was a way to express myself as a gay boy in a small town.ldquoKids can be cruel so starting to perform when I was at primary school and hanging out with other theatre kids was definitely my safe space ndash I found my tribe.ldquoI was worried about coming out as gay in a family of rugby fanatics, but my parents and family have always loved me unconditionally and were totally supportive ndash so much so that dad has become an accidental activist down the rugby club at times.Richie, who had always regularly ed to Penarth, hasnrsquot seen his family for a year due to coronavirus restrictions. One of the last times he was in Penarth was when he married Phil at the Paget Rooms.ldquoOur wedding was a testament to my familyrsquos love. Being able to celebrate in my home town with  of our favourite people was an amazing feeling.After leaving Penarth at , Richie ndash now aged  ndash headed to London where he toured with the  Tenors and produced backing vocals for John Barrowman, among plenty more impressive gigs.Richie and Phils wedding at Paget Rooms. Picture: Libby ChristensenHe first pitched up in Hamburg while working on a cruise ship in , and met Phil in a local bar.ldquoFrom then I was often in Hamburg, and when we got married I decided I wanted to stay here. Itrsquos a wonderful city and Irsquom trying to immerse myself in the culture.Thatrsquos easier said than done ndash as Richie found out on The Voice when the judges began speaking to him a little quickly in German.ldquoI know the basics butsomeone goes too fast Irsquom stuffed! Irsquom trying but itrsquos a very hard language, and so far I feel Irsquove got away with it because people here speak very good English.He says The Voice ndash which he fell into in February when he had a day off and heard the judges were in town ndash has given him a focus during a dficult time.He got through to the blind auditions after an audition in Hamburg.ldquoI felt when I moved here officially at the end of last year that my le was going to be very exciting this year, but that hasnrsquot panned out. Most engagements other than The Voice have been cancelled.Richie on set at The VoiceldquoMy studio recording projects came to a stand-still. I was supposed to be performing back in the UK at the Thursford Christmas Spectacular, but thatrsquos also been cancelled.ldquoI havenrsquot received any funding support, but fortunately as a self-employed performer I have savings that I have dipped into.ldquoMy husband works in PR at Google and he has been able to work from home full time.ldquoBut Irsquove become an excellent baker and Irsquove taken up pottery too.The lack of support for performers ndash especially in the UK ndash angers him, after seeing some of his friends who were working on the West End a few months ago now working in retail.ldquoTherersquos nothing wrong with working in a shop, but I feel as though therersquos been more respect for artists in Germany. The whole retrain message to performers is disgusting.Richie and Phil in Penarth last yearldquoYou wouldnrsquot tell doctors or teachers to retrain, and I feel wersquore not that valued ndash which is ridiculous. Wersquore surrounded by entertainment and art in all our lives.ldquoWe listen to the radio, we read the paper, we go to gigs and museums. How boring would like bewe just told creators to retrain While his Christmas shows are cancelled, he is hoping to be back in Penarth for Christmas.ldquoI canrsquot see a lot changing in the UK or Germany at the moment, but Irsquod love to be home soon. I was planning on going home four times this year, but Irsquove not been back once.ldquoItrsquos rubbish but Irsquom holding on to the knowledge that I will be back one day ndash hopefully in the not too distant future.Asked about his aspirations as a result of appearing on The Voice, he remained expertly modest.ldquoI donrsquot know. MaybeIrsquom back in town next Christmas theyrsquoll let me turn on the lights. Thatrsquod be a dream!Richies audition will be televised on German television on Sunday night, although he is hoping to share it on his social media channels.To follow Richies journey, check out his Instagram at richie.gooding and website at richiegoodingGet involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. In recent weeks they have taken  per cent of their earnings on Fridays and Saturdays, while a new Sunday dinner menu has been a hit.ldquoWe were sold out for Sunday this week and it will hit us hard not having those weekends, but wersquoll continue to operate a delivery service and wersquove already put together a takeaway menu with the help of new chef Damian Jones.They have had to furlough four staff members for the lockdown, and Mr Holland is hoping to get back to some form of normality from November , but he says he is not expecting that to be the case.Sian Fox, who runs Foxyrsquos cafeacute and deli, says she also believes cafes and pubs in Penarth have been unfairly judged.ldquoMy daughter is at university and knows lots of people who have coronavirus - I donrsquot think thatrsquos a coincidence, she said.Sian FoxldquoIrsquom grateful for phase three of the ERFwhich gives us a grant of pound,, and has helped us expand what we are doing online.ldquoOur deliveries have risen since the announcement on Monday. Similar to the last lockdown, when competition rises for supermarket delivery slots, people have come to us, and thatrsquos what has got us through. I hope it will again.ldquoI donrsquot know where it will end. I feel like wersquoll have this lockdown and then wersquoll have a month of trading indoors, and then therersquoll be another one.Angelina Hall, head of the Penarth Business Group and joint owner of Glass by Design, says the timing of the lockdown will inevitably hit traders hard.ldquoWith my retailer hat on, three weeks ago a lockdown would have meant curtailing the sp effectively and would have given us November and December to trade as well as possible given the circumstances, she said.Angelina HallldquoThat is now unlikely, and traders are going to lose a chunk of Christmas shopping time. The danger then is that Mr Amazon will take everyonersquos orders.
